product_title: Sony NWZ-W273 4GB Waterproof Walkman Sports MP3 Player
review_body: Honest Review: This product is not perfect, but I couldn't swim without it. I was on swim team all throughout middle school and high school but stopped after graduation. I loved swimming but the process of getting in and out of the pool was a pain and you can't even listen to music. I recently started lap swimming again as my primary exercise. I heard about these waterproof headphones from a friend and I was pumped to try them. I read the reviews, I knew what I was getting into with all the complaints. My main issue is that water still gets in through the sealed ear buds even though I sized them correctly. I usually lose sound in one ear after 15 minutes of swimming. When they dry the sound does goes back to normal in both ear buds. I cannot do flip turns or backstroke without them falling out. I use them for my warm up, cool down and light-moderate freestyle. They do have a more cons than pros but I am so happy that I can listen to music while swimming that I will take it.

product_title: SanDisk Sansa View 16 GB Video MP3 Player (Black)
review_body: This is a sleek-looking, overpriced and poorly engineered MP3 player. I bought it because I really liked my Sansa e200, but wanted more than the 4G of storage I had (2G of built-in memory, plus a 2G micro SD expansion card). I should have gotten an 8G e200 instead of the \\"View 16\\". The worst disappointment about this device is the short battery life. The manufacturer's claim of 32 hours of continuous music play time is sheer fantasy. I have never been able to get it to play more than 5-6 hours of MP3 without needing a charge. Moreover, charging is very slow. I had it plugged into the USB port of my PC at work for about 4 hours this morning (it had been nearly dead at the end of the day yesterday). I got maybe 2-3 hours of play, then it shut down and gave me a red battery icon when I tried to start it. The controls are also considerably inferior to the Sansa e200. The e200 has buttons around the blue volume dial that do what you would expect them to do--like traverse a menu vertically or horizontally. The View has a weird rubber-like washer that you're supposed to turn in order to navigate the menu or change the volume. It gives no tactile feedback whatever. I had to draw a mark on the rubber \\"washer\\" to determine whether it was actually turning or not (yes, it does turn, but the effects appear to be completely random). There are other bugs as well. For example, the display will often lag behind considerably; it will indicate that it is playing a song other than the one it is really playing...then suddenly it will update. I'm giving it two stars because it DOES play MP3s. For a short time. ------------------------ Update, 4 Sept 08 I still have this player, and am using it regularly at work to drown out the noise. (Yeah, and the voices...) Obviously, I'm not so dissatisfied that I returned this player. However, I still wish I'd bought the tried and true Sansa e-series instead. The mechanical design of the View is actually pretty good--thoughI still hate the rubber washer that you're supposed to turn to choose menu options. The problem was and remains the firmware. I've updated to the latest version (the one released in June 08), and I think play time has improved by about 25%. It's still far short of the promised 35 hours, but it will do for my purposes. However, the player continues to emit novel mutant behaviors. For example, the songs seem to multiply like bunnies. I'll select an artist or an album, and there will be about 8 to 10 entries for each of the songs that should be in the list. I'm sure the content hasn't actually been duplicated--I had about 20G of MP3s on there to begin with (have the 16G model with an 8G Micro SD card)--I think it's a database corruption issue. There's just numerous pointers to the same song. I have no idea how this happened--I've just been playing the music, and haven't downloaded new content via my PC. This is a major hassle, as I have to manually fast forward to the next song by skipping over the spurious entries. Putting the Sansa on random play means hearing the same songs over and over again, as it keeps finding the duplicate entries. Bah.

product_title: Mohu Leaf 30 TV Antenna, Indoor, 30 Mile Range, Original Paper-thin, Reversible, Paintable, 4K-Ready HDTV, 10 Foot Detachable Cable, Premium Materials for Performance, USA Made, MH-110583
review_body:
I've been paying over $20 a month for basic cable and, by basic, I mean about 10 broadcast channels. I finally bought my first digital TV (great deal on the LG 32LK330 here at Amazon) and wanted to change that. I didn't have high hopes -- the skyscrapers in Manhattan are notorious for making reception akin to living at the bottom of a canyon and, while I live fairly near the Empire State Building, my apartment faces away from it.

My TV is on the wall furthest from the windows but I didn't want to invest in an extension cable until I knew if this antenna would work at all. I screwed it in, ran a scan and had 52 channels with PERFECT reception. (TVGuide says there are 56 digital channels in my area but I don't think I'm going to bother with an extension to try to get the other 4.)

The Mohu Leaf is giving me 5 times as many channels and will pay for itself it 6 weeks. I'm only sorry I can't give it more than 5 stars.

review_body: I suspect the manufacturer knows he is making a piece of junk but the very low price will entice buyers. I have many MP3 CDs, mostly books but also music. You can get 10 hours on one CD. My Supersonic never worked with an a/c adapter, and you had to bang it and repeatedly press the buttons to get it working. After I played a few disks it just died and nothing could get it to work. Luckily more good old MP# CD players have recently appeared on the market and I ordered a Panasonic. If you need one stick to Sony or Panasonic. Also, can anyone explain to me why a seller is selling a new 12-year-old Panasonic at an insane price? I mean who is dumb enough to buy it when good used ones are selling 10 times cheaper.

review_body: I don't really know what else to write here. Well, for that they should just read the description given here on the product's Amazon.com web page; it is accurate. The iSkin I bought for my 80 GB iPod is of excellent quality and finish, and serves its purpose just as is claimed for it. In addition, I would also commend the company covercase.com which supplied it to me at Amazon's behest. The service was quick and packing good. I am surprised to see a reviewer's negative comments below concerning covercase.com, although the iSkin.com website was not as responsive concerning some queries regarding problems I had when fitting the plastic shield to the silicone case's guide lips. But they were simple enough for me to figure out myself after I had studied it more carefully.

product_title: Koss Porta Pro On Ear Headphones with Case
review_body:
These headphones provide great sound for the price, plus they're foldable, light, and pretty comfy. But the real reason the PortaPros get five stars is this: Koss stands behind their products. When a piece of plastic broke off my headphones (my own fault, really) I looked up my warranty and realized that I could get my headphones fixed for free. I was going to just buy the plastic piece and replace it myself, but Koss decided to send me a brand new pair in exchange for my old paid, plus pay for my return shipping. On top of that, Koss sent me the new version of the PortaPros.

Whenever anyone asks me what type of headphones to get, I always recommend Koss. Whether you want a cheap good pair, like these PortaPros, or a studio set, you can't beat Koss's customer service.

product_title: Cerwin Vega VE-5M 5-1/4" 2-Way Bookshelf Speaker (Pair)
review_headline: Forget Using These as Surround Speakers...
review_body:
Instead, set them up as the main speakers in a 2-channel stereo setup. They rock! Simple as that. Yeah, \\"only\\" 60 Hz., but damned if it ain't an honest 60 Hz.!

These speakers are really excellent for their size. They will almost take pretty much all you can throw at them (their impedance is 8 ohms, and they'll handle up to 125W peak), and at slightly saner listening levels, they are sweet, solid, punchy, balanced, articulate, clear, and just plain fun to listen to!

Get a pair, and try them for yourself. Jazz, Rock, Classical, these really deliver. Dub? Hip-Hop? They only go down to 60 Hz.! Toss in a sub, and you'll be doing pretty good! Otherwise, turn up the bass a little bit (they're only 5\\" drivers), and let them take you away!

Solid build, and solid sound. In my opinion, you really can't go wrong with these speakers. They are that good!

Update:
As I've been listening to these speakers, I am realizing that I really don't need to turn up the bass in order to get a solid sound! Even at lower volume levels, levels where you might consider switching in the Loudness button, I find that when leaving the Loudness off, and leaving the tone controls set flat, the sound is still very full and balanced, and the bass is solid without being boomy or otherwise smearing the rest of the sound! And when turned up with the tone controls flat, the sound is balanced, solid, and punchy; the percussive nature of the music comes through naturally.

Listening to Beethoven's 5th Symphony, the second movement, the quiet Double Bass notes are deep, rich, detailed, and solid. Listening to Steely Dan's song, \\"Babylon Sisters,\\" the sound is percussive, deep, sparkly, and clean! Dave Brubeck's \\"Take 5\\" is detailed, and natural. The bass sounds woody, deep, and very clean, and the drums are sharp and solid, with clean, and detailed cymbal sounds!

I keep focusing on the bass, and the percussive nature of the sound because that's what usually gets compromised in a small speaker system. In my opinion these speakers are well designed, and well executed. They continue to amaze me!

product_title: Omicron TURENO HDTV Speaker subwoofer
review_body: UP DATE AT BOTTOM. ordered the polk psw 1010 on a wedsney and receved it on a friday . im going to use it with the fluance 7.0 surrond system with the yamaha rxv671 recevier .sub is low cost price wise . could drop inhertz down to 25 . but for the price and make . you cant really beat it. quite a few years ago i had a yamaha rx 491 with paradigm atoms cc150 center and adp 10 sub with ads 100 dipole surrounds . for home theater and music . i still have the paradigme sub and sepreat crossover the polk comes close to low lows not quit as solid and wall and floor shakeing . but once again its pretty inpressive for the price . ide recemend it to a friend and others to buy it its vertisatel and works from music to ht systems. if your on a buget its a good choice and it comes in a few different colors. not bad . mh. ill keep an up date. posted. UP DATE . its 5/10/13. sub still works great. like i said i have paradigm subs. this will not go down as low or play as loud . but/ this only has a 100 whatt rms amp 50 watts contiouns. my paradigms have 300 and 200. thats a big difference. i also have def tech 8040s with built in 300 watt subs . in each speakers this is my main ht system . the polk is in our bed room with a yamaha rx-v 671 . and jamo speakers. alot of people dont take the tim to set up the speakers or sub . most just set it where they can plug it in and turn the knobs till they stop. not good. then say its muddy it clips it s not loud ect. all im saying is you have to spend a little time messing with it its a very decent sub for the price. theres subs out that cost more than this and sound terrable. i ran the yapo on the yamaha and set the speakers to larg to see . then changed them to small reran it and what a difference . it taks some time. no there not audiophile but for what they are and the price its a good buy. im pleased with it and would buy another one which im going to buy two more for my sons for there rooms . yes they have some port noise when pushed at higher volumes but the amp is 50 watts contiounus 100 is rms. i use it for ht and music and play it loud at times . it was designed for somuch and thats all. im pleased and would recamed this for someone on a budget or wants to keep cost down . i bought it on a whim it was cheap and looked decent . its polk . so there you have it . good luck .

product_title: APC LE1200 Line-R 1200VA Automatic Voltage Regulator
review_body:
I really have no way of testing the quality of this voltage regulator. All I know is that it's much bigger and heavier than I was expecting. I guess I didn't look at the specs closely enough.

It's 20.8cm x 13.2cm x 11.6cm and weighs a whopping eight pounds.

For years I had an APC UPS. The only annoyance was the battery doesn't last more than a year or two, and it was expensive to replace (the shipping on it was expensive, too). However, it was a very smooth sailing for my computer, over those years. I think the most important thing you can do is buy a quality motherboard and then protect it with a good voltage regulator such as this one. My feeling is that if you don't, you might get that one power surge when you weren't paying attention and it will weaken the board to where you'll have periodic blue-screen problems from then on out for years to come. I certainly don't trust the standard surge protectors which can be bought at the department store.

I just did $600 worth of upgrades to my computer and I needed to protect my investment.

product_title: DIRECTV RC71 Remote Control
review_body:
Let me preface this review by saying I have just started using this new remote (RC71) after years of using the \\"regular\\" DirecTV remote (RC65 universal IR remote).

First off, the back of the remote is a hard plastic with no sort of grippy texture or rubber coating so it is quite slippery, especially when you're using the top portion of the remote, which includes all the buttons except the number pad. I don't watch much live TV these days. I record everything and watch it later which means I rarely use the number pad and my hand is almost always towards the top of the remote using the playback functions (guide,list, menu, play, pause, record, etc). Also, because of the design of this remote and the fact that I use the top half almost exclusively, I always feel like I'm about the drop the remote because of how small it is and how it balances in my hand.

Another thing that really irks me is there is no STOP button like the old remote had and like you'd expect to find on a remote control that is supposed to be used to play recorded shows and movies. I'll tell you how I used my old remote so you can see why this is a problem for me. lets say I'm watching a recorded show and I want to stop it because I want to finish it later or im in the mood to watch another recording. I should be able to press STOP but there isn't a STOP button. So now I have to either hit pause (so the show doesn't continue to advance) then either hit the EXIT button (which takes you out to live TV) or hit LIST button then find another show to watch and play it. I can just hit the EXIT button to take me out of the show but that brings me to live TV and not to the list with my recordings.

Yet another thing that ticks me off is I can't delete a recording that I'm currently watching without going into the list. With the Old remote and old DVR, I was able to just hit the delete button and the currently playing recording would delete. Now I have to go to my list, go downto the recording I want to delete and press the delete button to get rid of it. Why all the extra steps?

With all this said, I should mention that I just upgraded to the DirecTV Genie. Maybe some of these issues are related to how the Genie works and not the remote itself. Either way, this remote does not feel good in the hand.

product_title: Orei DA Coaxial Premium To Analog Audio Decoder
review_body:
I got this converter to use with a legacy analog Bose Lifestyle 12 surround sound system (circa 1996). The Bose only has red/white analog inputs, and my LG flatscreen and Cisco cable box only have digital audio outputs. So I purchased an optical cable, ran it from the Cisco to the Orei converter, then ran red/white audio cables from the Orei to the Bose. Everything works perfectly. Just for grins, I also ran a coax digital from another Seiki flatscreen, to the Orei (has to throw the little selector switch on the Orei), and then to the Bose, and it also works perfectly.

I am very happy with this purchase.

product_title: Barnes & Noble Nook Simple Touch eBook Reader (Wi-Fi Only)
review_body:
E-ink displays do not require a back light in order to display an image, this results in a less stressful experience for your eyes. Also, e-ink displays are easier to view in sunlight, this device is perfect for anyone that wants to read outdoors and have a large volume of books at your finger tips. These displays only use power to update the image on the display. Once the image has been updated, the display no longer consumes precious battery life. Meaning this device can actually last weeks/months on a single charge. The draw back is due to the update once scheme, the device may feel a bit sluggish to people use to tablets. This device was only designed as a reading device, therefore a quick response time should not be an issue.

This device exceeded my expectations, easily copy and pasted my pdfs from my computer onto the device in a few mouse clicks. I would recommend this device to people who hate reading on LCD screens and prefer physical copies of books.

product_title: Altec Lansing iM227 Orbit MP3 Speaker
review_headline: Blew me away. *WAY* better than iHome iHM9U
review_body:
I hesitated to buy this speaker, since I already had an external speaker for my mp3 player. But I was never really happy with the iHome iHM9U I had. It had been an impulse buy a couple years ago. When I plugged this Altec product in, I really wish I hadn't waited so long. No comparison between the sound. The iM227 is much louder, much clearer sound. Richer tones, and everything else about it just rocked. Rather than sounding muffled, it filled the room with decent sound. Yes, my home theater system is still nicer, but this Orbit speaker sounds more like it than like the dumb little pansy speaker I had before. And it's smaller, and easier to transport. What's not to love? I'm convinced this is the best product available for anywhere near this price.

Just get it, you won't regret it.

UPDATE: There's another (newer?) model of this product that includes 3 AAA batteries and an adapter that will connect the unit to devices with a 2.5mm plug (this model doesn't include batteries or the adapter). And, it's cheaper than this listing on Amazon (right now). I believe that other than those extra included items, it's an identical product. Check out the [[ASIN:B006KZ0R1Q Altec Lansing Technologies IMT227 OrbitM Ultra Portable Speakers]]. I'd suggest getting that instead.

product_title: Sony NWZS616FPNK 4GB Walkman Video MP3 Player (Pink)
review_headline: You can use it with iTunes!
review_body: I bought this to replace an old iPod mini. The battery in this is incredible - I can go for weeks without charging it, and I use it at least five days a week. You can definitely still use iTunes with this Walkman. It can play M4A files, which are what type of files are created by iTunes when you import a cd. If you buy music from the iTunes store, they will be M4P files (unless they are the new DRM-free format.) You can just burn your M4P files onto a cd and import the cd back into iTunes. You can open your iTunes music folder and drag and drop the songs onto your Walkman as though it were a memory stick. Very handy.

product_title: Apple iPod touch 8GB (4th Generation)
review_body: The 4th generation Apple iPod Touch is the best music player out there in my opinion! I highly recommend it. The camera is pretty good; it takes pictures and video in 1080 pixels (1080p). Also, it is pretty fast. I wouldn't recommend any other music player. This is the one to get!

product_title: FiiO E6 Portable Audio Headphone Amplifier
review_headline: Still lower noise floor than the newer models
review_body: Bit short on battery life but that seems to be par for the course with mini amps in this class. Where the E6 still shines is in its low noise floor. I generally use this class of amps with IEMs while on the road but o I have compared this with the E3 and the newest Rocky and even with bass boosted I have a nearly silent background with the E6 and 16 Ohm IEMs. The Rocky, in comparison, has quite a bit of noise that persists with 32ohm Grados with amplification and bass on. This may be a function of having bass boost, amplification, and a microphone circuit crammed in there. But, there you go. If you don't need the mic and you don't have any particular preference for the controls (the E3 is significantly harder to manage in your pocket or such) the E3 seems to be the better package for pure listening. A solid worker at an acceptable price point, which seems to be the hallmark of Fiio.

product_title: Creative MuVo TX FM 256 MB MP3 Player
review_headline: One of the best MP3 players out there. Gym Savvy!
review_body:
This is one AWESOME MP3 player. It has so many features and the fact thats they are also easy to use makes it even better. I may have had it for a few hours, but that's all I (and most people) need to operate this player to it full extent. I have made a pros and cons list as well.

PROS:
MENU SYSTEM - This is GREAT! It's so easy to use because of the icons and the scoller button. One of those players that you could operate out of the box without the manual.

SIZE - It's VERY small for an MP3 player. I can't say it's an amazing size because I came from an Panason SV-SD80 (THAT player, by the way, is INCREDIBLY TINY! The size of a psotage stamp). But the size DEFINITELY pocketable.

SCREEN - It has a nice blue backlit screen. Some people says it's too small, but I don't think so. It displays the battery life, time elapsed, type of EQ (equalizer), and song name (NOT artist). The only showing the song name is a little bad, but it doesn't seem to bother me much. Technically, you DO get the see the artist's name because right before you select the song, it displays the file name. If you put the artist's name in the file name, you get the see it for a split second.

Accessories - It comes with Creative earbuds, a belt clip, and an armbamd. The earbuds are nice sounding, but they are so big and thick in my ears that it hurts them after 5 minutes. The belt clip is rubber, which does WONDERS to the plastic surface of the MuVo. It grips the player. Plus, the way the belt slip is designed, you must stick in the key ring side of the player, so the MuVo's keyring goes into the keyring hole. That way, the player cannot fall out. That was hard to explain; it's something that you must buy the player or see the belt clip in order to understand. The armbad is actually nice to use. Not hard to use and the player is VERY safe. To use the armband, you have to use it with the belt clip, even safer.

SOUND - The sound was GREAT when I first used it. Then it got even better when I setup my settings for the custom EQ. NOW it sounds AMAZING. Plus, now I can actually hear nice music coming from Sony Street style headphones (I couldn't before on my Panasonic)

TRANSFER - SOOOOOO FAST! The USB 2.0 is amanzing when it's on an MP3 player AND a thumb drive. I LOVE the drag and dropp ability of the Muvo. My panasonin had to use Realplayer to transfer the songs. ABSOLUTELY ANNOYING! Now I have no fustration. Drag and drop and I outta the house.

FM RADIO AND VOICE RECODER- GREAT I just autoscan for the radio station. I don't know how many presets it can save total, but when I autoscaned, I got 16. still impressive. I don't have picky ears, so the FM radio recorder was nice to have and listen to. Voice recoder is nice but not high quality. Can't expect much from an MP3 player.

PRICE - I think it is a plus because you get all these things all together in one packeage: MP3 player, Voice recoder, FM radio/recorder, and flash drive. Plus, the original 256 MB MuVo TX that had NO FM radio was more expensive than this one. Funny, huh?

CONS:
NOT RECHARGEABLE OUT OF THE BOX - It didn't come with rechargeble batteries. It was kind of sucky, but I cant juss buy either ALOT of AAA batties, or a rechargeble battery kit.

NO LANYARD - It didn't come with a neck strap. I kind of like those because if you don't want to use the belt clip or armband, but still hands free, a neck strap would be nice.

NO DISPLAY OF ARTIST'S NAME

SIZE - I had said that size was a PRO of the player, but it's also a CON. When you separate the player and the battery pack to plug in the player, you'll notice that the player will take up the space of 2 PORTS. Kind of annoying for some people since for me, I don't have that many USB peripherals. I'm just telling those people who DO have all USB ports filled and a USB HUB. Other than that,size is still a PRO

Memory - Although 256 MB is actually ALOT more than I expected, it would be nice to have a 512MB version or even a 1GB version of this AWESOME player. 256 MB is definitely plenty for the average user and even above the average user.

All and all, VERY nice player. When I rate this player, I have no doubt in my mind taht is deserves a 5.

product_title: AKG Q701 Quincy Jones Signature Reference-Class Premium Headphones
review_headline: Fantastic headphones! Put your bass fears to bed.
review_body:
If you're looking at these headphones, you must already know about head-fi. A good consumer would have read their reviews, and if you're like me, been terrified of the anemic low-end.

There is NO NEED TO FRET.

My primary pair of headphones before I picked these up were the Sony MDR-XB500 (XB for Xtra bass, bro). Transitioning between them does not make me feel a lack of bass. It is absolutely less dramatic bass response, but I don't feel like I'm missing anything. Bass tracks I fell in love with on my Sony's (Dead Man's Tetris by Flying Lotus is currently playing) sounds great and full, with clarity and articulation that doesn't need the "Xtra Bass" bloat.

AND THE SOUNDSTAGE! Good lord, these feel so enormous! The way things move feels effortless, and the sound envelops you like a blanket fresh from
The dryer.(that is NOT saying it's a warm can; imagery only)

These headphones are clear too! The texture of woodwinds comes across so exquisitely, i can feel the texture of the reed on my lips.

I had concerns about the treble reproduction on these headphones, and I will say the treble (the hanging ring of bells for example) can be a tad aggressive, but by no means a deal breaker. That agressiveness has been defining in certain tracks, showing me more of what I was there to see.

Lastly, I was concerned about the need of a headphone amp with these cans. While i'll still be buying an amp (little dot 1+) everything you've read has been experienced through my iPhone. I'm very excited to see how these will sound with an amp, but It's great knowing they're not lifeless without one!

As My first pair of audiophile quality headphones, I feel these are a great selection, but I was almost scared out of buying them after reading reviews on head-fi. I'm glad I went with my gut.

product_title: Onkyo TX-SR605 7.1 Channel Home Theater Receiver
review_body: Too early to give a full review of the SR605, although I can say that set up has been very easy and so far DVD sound is quite good. I like the automatic sound adjustment on first use. My complaint, or question for anyone that might have ideas on how to resolve, is that it does not seem to work as passthrough for Xbox 360 using component output. I hooked Xbox component output into SR605, HDMI output from SR605 to Aquos LCD TV. No video image. I wonder if this is due to XBOX outputting in 1080p, and SR605 converter having difficulty passing 1080p from component input to HDMI output. Onkyo support site has no answer to this. To resolve, I hooked Xbox component output directly to TV, but this means I have to switch TV input every time. One of the big advantages of SR605 is that you use it as the input/output switch, theoretically not having to switch TV input to change sources. Now for my, uh, kids (cough, cough) to play Xbox, we have to switch both SR605 and TV inputs. Any solution to this, or is this just a SR605 flaw?

product_title: Monster Cable TGHZ-2RF Two Gigahertz Low-Loss RF Splitters For TV and Satellite 2-Way 2 Gigahertz RF Splitter (Discontinued by Manufacturer)
review_headline: One of few Monster products that's worth the price.
review_body: While I'm no big fan of typically over-priced and over-hyped Monster products, I'll readily concede that this beats any of the 9 or 10 other splitters I tried. I see comments here from users who say they can't see a difference with this product; my comment to them is that they need a better tv. I also noted one reviewer who somehow heard that this splitter can't be used with CATV (It can, and I've been using mine for over a year with my digital cable hookup). Advantages: less noise and grain than others I've used, and channels at the frequency band extremes look much better than my cable company's \\"free\\" piece of junk. Most notably, this splitter maintains excellent image contrast and has no visible chroma effects that I can see. Few splitters can manage all this. The only product I've tried that might beat this is a $[...] job whose brand I don't remember (probably because I ain't spending $[...] on a splitter, for any reason). Even if you're not crazy about Monster in general, you'll get your money's worth here. I'm using two in my setup with a CELabs booster amp.

product_title: Sangean SG-622 FM / MW / SW 1-10 Compact 12 Band World Receiver
review_headline: Fun Radio for "tuning around" on Shortwave
review_body:
This is an \\"old fashioned\\" dial and pointer radio, lacking all of the features of a modern digital set... no preset stations, poor indication of the actual frequency that is tuned, no clock, no alarm. Somehow, it is still great fun to use!

Band scanning has been a weak point of digital radios... the sound is usually muted while slewing through the frequency range, leaving just a tuning indicator light to show that a station has been found (most will not stop scanning on weak signals), or if not muted, a loud \\"chuffing\\" noise is produced as the frequencies are scanned. With this set you just turn the knob and listen for stations!

If you want to easily find, say the BBC on 5.975 Mhz a digital radio will get you there much faster, but for scanning the band to see what is on, the old dial and pointer still works quite well!

For a similar but smaller and slightly less expensive radio, see my review of the Kaito WRX911. For a more expensive radio with \\"Double Conversion\\", which eliminates \\"false signals\\" on shortwave, see my review of the Kaito KA1107.

product_title: thinksound rain 9mm In-Ear Wooden Headphone with Enhanced Bass and Passive Noise Isolation
review_body: Six years ago when I got my first iPod I discovered that the standard ear buds would not fit my ears. It wasn't that they were uncomfortable; they would NOT physically even fit in my tiny ears. If I tried to put them in they would actively \\"pop\\" (not just fall) out. At the time I ordered a second set of ear buds from Apple -- these had three sets of padding in various sizes. I thought surely the smallest size would work, but they did not. I then searched for reviews of ear buds that would accommodate tiny ears, but to no avail. I tried ordering a few other brands, but never had any luck. I settled for some large, noise-cancelling headphones and just gave up my quest for a smaller solution. I had concluded that my ears are just absurdly small and I was out of luck. However, I recently renewed my search and found a couple of helpful lists of the \\"best\\" ear buds for small ears (notably an excellent one from CNET: [...]). I ordered two pairs: this brand and a JVC Marshmallow set that were both reviewed in the CNET article. While I was prepared to be happy with the cheaper JVC set, I was glad I ordered both sets as these Thinksound Rain headphones had a much wider range of small tip sizes. The JVC set, which had several positive reviews about being suitable for small ears, were not nearly small enough for me. However, I could actually use the second smallest Thinksound Rain earpiece set! It's a miracle! If you are looking for ear buds with a range of options for truly tiny ears, these are terrific.

product_title: Lark Silent Alarm Clock
review_body:
I was very excited when I first heard of this product. However, it didn't really met my expectations. After a half year of usage it's now resting on the bottom of the closet. It's quite OK, although the setup is a bit complicated.

There are three reasons why I wouldn't recommend it:
1. It's just a device that wakes you up at the time you set. I can't even remember myself using some of the other features. Not to mention, it's a bit uncomfortable wearing such device on your hand when you go to sleep.
2. You can't really use it for polyphasic sleep. It will always tell you that you didn't sleep enough, because it doesn't accumulate the time you spend sleeping during the day.
3. Considering what I wrote above, it's a VERY expensive alarm clock.

The volume buttons are easy enough to use, and turning it off was easy too. Not sure if I was exercising it would be as easy. I use my iPod for that I'm sure if I needed to I would use the headphones. It was a little tight but maybe there are instructions, I didn't read too closely, to loosen them. I love wireless don't you?

The dh listened to music on the TV this morning also and really liked the sound of the music. I may get brave enough to try my iPod with it too. It was a Bluetooth hookup too.

I'm looking forward to all the uses I'll get to use the headset for. The headphones were packaged interestingly--what a great plastic box! Grandson will probably have a good time with it lol

product_title: MEElectronics Sports Sound-Isolating In Ear Headphones with Microphone/Remote for iPod
review_body:
Pros:
1. Good for long distance running as they sit in your ear and need adjustments only a few times during the run.
2. The memory wire is very helpful and holds the earpiece in place with minimal irritation or creating any pressure on your ears

Cons:
1. The \\"with Microphone/Remote\\" may lead customers o believe that it has remote volume control, which it does not. That is why I give it 3 stars. The seller should come clean and make it clear in the technical summary on the top that it does NOT have remote volume control.
2. The headset inserted for a good fit gives you good sound and bass but if you are running it also creates a thumping feeling with every step you take. That will negate the advantage of \\"quiet listening\\" and will make any runner to loosen the inserts a little bit. I do not have any other comparable in the ear headset that I can compare it to.

product_title: Clip Plus 4 GB MP3 Player (Black)
review_body:
I love this little guy, I love this MP3 player so much I've replaced it three times. But after today I realized that I need to find a new brand or model. I have had similar issues with all three, but the first lasted much longer, and the one I have now is already crapping out on me after a few months. One consistent issue is the headphone jack somehow becomes damaged and will only play music on either just the left side or just the right side of the headphone. If I fiddle with it it will play in both ears for a few minutes, but the time and attention it takes to have the music play in both ears continuously is not worth it. The player also freezes and other times will not turn on unless you press down the On button for several seconds.

If you're looking for something that will last a couple of years, this MP3 player is not it.

I have an Onkyo RC360 receiver, 46\\" Samsung LCD, Pana Bluray, TW cable, HTPC and Harmony cradle plugged into this thing. Cheers,

product_title: Nyrius Media Fusion TV Dock for iPod/iPhone
review_headline: Didn't do much for me, figuratively or literally
review_body:
I can see the point of a tool like this, and I suppose if I didn't have access to my [[ASIN:B003L1ZYYM AmazonBasics High-Speed HDMI Cable (6.5 Feet/2.0 Meters)]] and a couple of adapters for my various Apple devices, I'd have tried harder to make it work. But since I do, the problems and disappointing performance of this Media Fusion TV Dock means it went right back in the box.

I have an HD TV and, while not huge in relative terms, it was big enough to make the poor-quality graphics of the Nyrius display painful to look at. I would comment on the quality of the video reproduction, but none of the four video podcasts I tried to play showed up on screen -- audio yes, video no, and although I have 10 movies stored on my iPhone at the moment, this dock couldn't locate any of them (I question whether this dock is fully compatible with iOS 5). I could have tried showing photos on screen, but to get to the photo display, you have to manipulate the iPhone yourself via the touchscreen, which kind of defeats the purpose of having a remote.

Music playback was fine. It would have been nice if the Nyrius showed album art on screen, but it doesn't.

I know using a cable is still a step or two below wireless playback with AirPlay and/or an Apple TV. But until I get there, I will stick with my HDMI cable. It works a lot better for me than this product did.

product_title: Outdoor Tech Big Turtle Shell - Rugged Bluetooth 4.0 Wireless Boombox & Powerbank
review_body: Based on the number of positive reviews, my experience may be somewhat of an outlier. I purchased the BTS via the Kickstarter campaign and received the unit in July. The unit arrived undamaged and partially charged. After getting it paired with my iPhone, I played some music off Pandora and noticed that the sound was distorted. Additionally, when the battery went low the speaker's voice began giving me the "charge me" indication. I plugged the unit in and, after being plugged in for quite some time, the "charge me" indication continued. Eventually, the battery died, while plugged in. I contacted Outdoor Tech and they sent me another charging cable/transformer. The new cable cured the charging problem. However, the biggest problem was the issue of the terribly distorted audio quality. The distortion manifests itself in a high(er) frequency buzzing/rattling sound as music is being played. I'm assuming that the speaker driver is either loose or defective or there is an issue with the enclosure. I appreciate high quality sound and happen to notice poor audio quality quite easily, my wife does not and yet she commented on the poor audio quality. I contacted Outdoor Tech again and they sent me a return authorization form. Due to my frustration with the unit (and the serious let down after FINALLY receiving the unit) I put it in a drawer and never sent it back. I just sent an email to Outdoor Tech to see if they will still rectify the situation and will update this review once I see how they will handle it. It is somewhat frustrating when a mail/web order item is defective considering the pain and inconvenience it is to deal with the RMA system and then, again, WAIT for a unit that hopefully does what it is advertised to do.

review_headline: Sony Walkman Portable Skip-Free CD Player is remarkable
review_body: We got this because our farm truck's (a ford f250hd) CD player went south. Since then, we've used it without fail. The Walkman has bounced off the front seat numerous times as the two of us are listening to e-Books, and never skipped a syllable! We're able to resume from where we left off by virtue of the fact we just don't remove the CD until we're ready to start listening again. I'm guessing there's a flash-mem which retains the current track position. Nonetheless, the Walkman is built sturdy and works well. And when we switch to the town car, we're still able to keep following the latest e-Book we have, right from where we let off. We love it!

product_title: MEElectronics Sport-Fi M6 Noise Isolating In-Ear Headphones with Memory Wire
review_headline: Won me over in 2 seconds; perfect for running
review_body:
I've always been a Sennheiser fan but I also own about 20 different earbuds/headsets across 10 different brands. The quest for the perfect earbuds for running has ended. At the same time, the quests for the perfect earbuds for the plane, at work, and just about anything else have also ended. These MEElectronics M6 earbuds are amazing! After listening to them, I would pay $100 if that was the going price.

PROS
- Fits perfectly out of the box (six pairs of ear pieces to ensure find one that you can get a tight seal with)
- Very good highs, mids, and lows -- if you can't hear/feel the bass, then try a different ear piece to get that seal
- Amazingly comfortable even though this is deep in my ear canal
- Does not move at all during running; I can turn my head, do jumping jacks, etc... they stay in place
- Isolates from other noises -- no active noise cancelling but it will block noise, including your own voice when you speak
- Cord management is well thought-out; not only does it have a clip but it also has tightener where the left/right wires come together

CONS
- Since a tight seal is necessary, I can hear the sound of the cords rubbing against my body when I'm running; in order to minimize that, I need to hang the cord in the front and not the back

OVERALL
I really wish I bought these sooner. I'm glad I found a set of earbuds that are no longer 'just good enough' but actually motivates me to put them on and go for a run! The best $20 I've ever spent.

The sound is better than my old Sony headset, which is nice, although I had no issues with the Sony. It does require a separate receiver, which isn't cheap. That was an unpleasant shock. This is a great mouse pad and paying the extra $20 to get this than a cheap one is defiantly worth it because it works so much better for when I am PC Gaming.

review_body: Usually I only spend 5 bucks for headphones, and they wind up going out after a couple of weeks. Those headphones were never the greatest quality to begin with. product_title: URC R50 Digital Universal Remote Control for up to 18 Components (Discontinued by Manufacturer)
review_body: I purchased this device to replace three remotes and most importantly the remote provided for the DVR by my cable provider. The remote for the DVR also controls the TV and thus is the primary remote. However, its keys are difficult to push and my thumb was starting to get sore with use. I chose this remote because reviewers indicated it was reliable, sturdy and flexible. I agree that this remote is sturdy. You drop it and it keeps on working. The keys are easy to push with my thumb or fingers and minimal resistance. The side keys are a little small and not as convenient as the larger keys that control most of the functions. The side keys control up/dn for volume and channels, and certain functions of playback. They are OK once you adapt to the remote. The instructions are minimal in the print form but they are provided as a type of help function when you program the remote. It took me about 30 minutes to read the instructions and learn the basic programming method. My wife would never have figured it out. You need some technological sense to program it. Once you figure it out, then it becomes fairly easy to do. I was able to program it easily for my DVR (cable) and TV. The DVR box was Magnavox and the TV Panasonic. My DVD player is Panasonic would not accept a code number so I had to program it button by button. That is not fun and it is not as flexible. I programmed it to turn on the DVD but then I use the controls of the DVD to play, etc, as the button by button controls are not as flexible or intuitive. If all the devices had been programmed by using a code number I would have given it a 5 star. Even though I was not able to program the DVD I give it a 4 star because it is reliable and controls properly the DVR and TV, which I mostly used. If someone is challenged by technology I would not recommend it unless you have someone in the house who could set it up for you or trouble shoot it.

product_title: La Crosse Technology BC-700 Alpha Power Battery Charger
review_body: A little pricier than other chargers, but well worth it. the combo of this charger and the eneloop batteries is absolutely the way to go.

product_title: Smart&Safe® Hollow Air Tube Hands-free Headset - Reduces 98% of Harmful Radiation Emissions Generated By Cellphones - Compatible with iPhone & Blackberry and all Cellphones with 3.5mm Jack
review_body:
I think the relatively high price for these requires the product be a premium product. Unfortunately it is not. Although the sound quality is great (really), and the tubes are the longest I've seen (best EMF exposure reduction from user), and the comfort is fantastic (triple-flanged rubber ear-inserts)...the sad part is that it malfunctioned only a few weeks after pruchase, and I hardly used it all (maybe 50 times). Currently I can hear the other person, but they can't hear me. Probably a break in one of the wires somewhere. Also: one of the triple-flanged ear inserts split and now doesn't attach anymore. I can't figure out how to contact the seller as Amazon says it's no longer eligible for a return.

P.S. I also bought the \\"Natural Health Alternatives Black Hollow Air Tube Anti-Radiation Headset Stereo Model Emf Protector\\" at the exact same time as a backup (thankfully) and it works well. It also has good sound-quality (almost as good as Smart&Safe), but is only half as comfortable, and the tubes aren't as long (less EMF reduction to user). Oddly, it's unfortunately REALLY loud, such that phone calls actually hurt my ears, even with the phone volume turned ALL the way down. I don't remember having this excessive volume problem with the Smart&Safe. I recall that the volume was just right.

If they can improve the quality on the Smart&Safe, it would be nearly perfect (needs its own volume control though). Unfortunately, it's way overpriced for something that only lasts a few weeks.

product_title: Gefen HDmi Detective Plus
review_body: My setup is relatively simple. I have a media center pc that I use for both my regular TV and my theater room. The media center (Windows 7) had problems when I would switch from my TV to my projector. It was really frustrating because of course it happened most when I had guests over. Just switching the device from TV to project or back would frequently cause the media center to blue screen and die. Since I've installed this device I have had absolutely no problems with the media center. It always works when I need it do. I believe that the product is a little over priced at around $100, but it does work.

product_title: Etymotic Research HF2 Earphones / Headset (iPhone Compatible)
review_headline: On my third pair so far, and still madly in love with them...
review_body: Like the title says, I'm concurrently on my third pair. The first pair (purchased in late 2009) had a design defect in the headphonejack that broke the wires on the inside after about a years worth of use. A short email later I got a RMA number, returned the old broken pair and within about 2 weeks was sent what I'm assuming were a refurbished pair that had a redesigned headphone jack. These in turn worked great for a few months until they too stopped working. These also had a problem with the headphone jack, this time a material defect. A bit of exposed wire in the jack caused the sound to cut in and out. A short email later I was given another RMA number and sent a pair of BRAND new buds. So with all of tht in mind, how can I give these buds a five star rating?... Well tbw, they sound incredible! These are some seriously nice earbuds. The mids sound great, and unlike most contemporary buds the bass won't drown everything else out (not that there's anything wrong with the bass on these btw). These are some incredibly well balanced buds. They also drown out most ambient sound when in. I love the matte finish, and their inconspicuous design! They also come with a handy clip you can use to attach them to your shirt so they don't flap around when worn (that I broke after a while that they replaced for FREE!), have an inline mic, and Controls that work with almost any Android phone! As a Android user awash in a sea full of iOnly compatible accessories I can't tell you how refreshing it is to have accessory that's fully compatible with my phone of choice! So, in addition to some awesome sounding and looking buds (as evidenced by the countless other reviews I'm sure), the real killer feature that sets these these buds apart from any other in the same price range is the company that stands behind them. What other company would go to the lengths they did to honor their product like they did almost two years after my initial purchase? Not many I'm guessing, and that's whywhenever I need a new pair sometime in the future they'll be Etymotics.

So apparently some design or quality issues, not at all what you'd expect at this price point. And the return via FedEx GROUND is a nice touch Peachtree. UPDATE: Eventually the amplifier arrived. The volume knob no longer makes noise, but there's intermittent static-y noise, even without a source connected, which was not there before. I'm returning it.

product_title: Yamaha 2-Way Indoor/Outdoor Speakers (Pair)
review_headline: OK for the money, some issues
review_body: The sound on these doesn't blow me away but is fine for outdoor patio use. They can get plenty loud and the price was definitely a good deal. I only really have had two issues thus far. First of all, if you plan on mounting these any way but straight off a wall, plan on purchasing additional mounting hardware. The instructions mention some sort of 'mega' bracket, which is a joke. I scoured the net and found others baffled by this phantom mounting device. Yamaha is doing a disservice to it's customers by even printing this in the enclosed documentation. I needed to mount these on the patio ceiling but did end up finding a great bracket that is sturdy and has quite a bit of flexibility. The bracket is item number 10776 from a1components.com. I'm sure you can find it elsewhere but it is very sturdy, made of metal and not plastic. Best of all it was only $13 per bracket. It did the trick for ceiling mounting. The other issue is the grills just fall off. After only about two weeks outside, the grills just dropped right off. I live in Texas but the speakers are completely out of the sun. I had to strap rubber bands around the speaker bodies to keep the grills on. It's not attractive but seems to work. It seems like a better design would include a simple clip in of the grills instead of using glue. The Yamaha engineers must not have tested the glue above 80 degrees F.

product_title: Cable Matters 2 Pack, 90 Degree HDMI Male to Female Adapter

product_title: Pyle PT390AU Digital Home Theater Stereo Receiver, Aux (3.5mm) Input, MP3/USB/AM/FM Radio, (2) Mic Inputs, 300 Watt
review_body: Works great with the wall mount speakers I bought. This item came double boxed and was shipped out very quickly. Very happy with this one.

product_title: Qinpu - A-6000 MKII - Integrated /Headphone Amplifier
review_body:
Overall Impression

I just picked one of these up based on the reviews on Amazon as well as a few reviews on here. And while I is a dual purpose integrated hybrid/tube amp and headphone amp, this amp really earns its money as the integrated amp. It does the headphone thing pretty good, but I have to be honest. I can not say that it is better than a properly configured Asus STX's headphone out, but its only marginally more expensive than the soundcard. But, I do not think I would be doing this thing justice without talking about its speaker driving abilities as an integrated amp. As an amplifier, most will rule it out due to its limited specs of 16.5 watts @ 8 ohms.Well, I have to say this things sounds better than two of my $800 Integrateds (NAD and Sony ES). If you have somewhat efficient speakers and not trying to fill a large room, this thing will drive speakers to loud but enjoyable volumes with ease. This is perfect for an office or bedroom. This thing has a tremendous soundstage and plenty of low end grunt, without sounding bloated for exaggerated, even through bookshelf speakers, Even with a flat eq setting on the STX, it sound full an balanced with the right amount of glassy sparkle with a touch of midrange complexity.

Tubes

These take 6N3 or equivalents. As for tube rolling, I feel a lot of people get caught up into it so much that they hear things based more on expectations than reality. Judging tubes is one thing that I feel I am more experienced in than a lot of people, as I've not only been using them for 30 years, I've also done a lot of tube amp repair work, as well as some building and modification for professional musicians. Although most of my experience is on the guitar amp side, I can assure you that guitarists are just as picky as audiophiles. I started out with the stock Chinese tubes, which appear to be Shuguang. I also bout about 4 sets of GE 5670W's. The thing people miss about tubes is that the tolerance for any manufacturer is all over the map. The output on one tube from the same maker can be up to 30% from the next tube of the line. If you have a tested or a reliable vendor that measures and tests tubes, I contend that a cheap tube that is strong and within spec with sound nearly as good as the expensive tube within the same specs. No guarantee just because its more expensive it will sound better. The other point I would like to make is that most designers design around evaluations done with a specific tube. So, they tweak according to what they are hearing with a specific tube. In my case I think the stock tube sounds better than the GE tubes. The GE tubes sound as if they have more gain, resulting in a little more boomy sound, but the stock tubes sound more natural to me. Both tubes have pretty small plates and seem quiet and free from microphonics.

Conclusion

I highly recommend this amp for a study or bedrooms. It's simple looks cool and sounds like an amp 3 times its price. I promise you that you will be surprised the sound that comes from this thing. As for the headphone amp, I think this may be overkill for just that. I rate is a very good, but not OMG good.

FLAC -> Asus STX -> Qinpu A-6000 Mk2 -> Kimber 4VS Kables -> Dali Lektor 3 speakers

product_title: Sony MDR-G45LP (Black)
review_body: I have had these headphones for over a year after I tried out about 2 other pairs from different brands, both of which either sounded muddy or tinny. These headphones have clear sound and satisfying bass, for the price you really cant complain. I paid almost $30 for these at Circuit City and I would do it again. I take them with me everywhere and use them with my laptop, DS and portable DVD player. I listen to all sorts of music, everything from metal to dubstep and I dont have any complaints with how these deliver the sound. For sure they are the best in this price range, period. My only complaint is they do get uncomfortable, I wear them for hours on end occasionally (gaming or listening to tons of music) and when I take them off my ears really ache and are kinda numb. They lack good cushioning. Also, as some of the other reviews have mentioned, they do tend to move around a bit on your ears and can affect the sound but just a quick reajustment and they are back in full. I would recommend these headphones to anyone that casually listenens to music or just wants to watch some Youtube vids. If your gonna be wearing them for more than an hour or so then you will need to give your ears a break for a few minutes every now and then. The bottom line: for the price you cant beat them, love the sound, they are tough, look good and as long as you give your ears a rest occasionally they will be fine.

product_title: JAM XT Extreme Wireless Speaker

product_title: JBL Loft 30 Two-Way 4" Bookshelf Loudspeaker - Pair (Black)
review_headline: Best Bookshelf Speaker in the <$50 category
review_body: These are simple 2-way design with a 4" midrange and 1" soft some tweeter. These are a great example of what can happen when you take two modest components and execute the design with well chosen crossover points and enclosure design. You get a great sounding speaker with a surprising response in the low end, warm, detailed midrange and a clean upper register that after 4hrs did not produce a hint of fatigue that often plague the listener with lower end speakers. I was convinced that I would need to turn on the powered sub to round out the sound stage, but to my surprise this wasn't absolutely necessary with jazz, acoustic rock and blues. I'm not saying these speakers will produce tons of bass, but their well designed ported enclosure allows a much fuller low to midrange transition than a lot fo speakers I've demo'd that, despite significantly higher cost, are lost without the help of a subwoofer. So it's IMHO, that I would say these are the best bookshelf speakers I have heard in the sub $50 category. I've seen them at local big big stores with their "promo codes" in the sub $40 region and for that they are an absolute steal.

product_title: Audio Technica Replacement Ear Pads for ATH-M40fs Headphones (Pair)
review_body: One of the selling features of the Audio-Technica (AT) headphone series is that the ear pads are replaceable. I suspect there are many users that considered that a "nice-to-have" feature, but not something they would ever cash in on. This particular set of headphones advertised flat response (fs). Accordingly they replaced a more expensive set of DJ headphones I had been using for pleasure listening since DJ headphones usually emphasize the bass. With the flat response of these ATH-M40fs, I have been able to use them for rough mixes. So much so, that (even with an acoustically imperfect room), I have figured out how to mix with these--and then afterward have developed a consistent tweak of the EQ for the masters. These headphones allow one to do rough to nearly final mixes (final mix with studio speakers, of course). Consequently, after considerable studio hours, the material covering the earpads started to disintegrate. How great not to have to replace the whole shootin' match when the headphones themselves are still kickin'! This set of headphones (and the replaceable earpads) are definitely one of my best studio purchases!

product_title: Sharkk 15W Bluetooth Wireless Speaker with Built-in Power Bank, 10 Hour Playtime, Single
review_headline: Solid Speaker/Power Bank - perfect for the category
review_body: I was provided with a free copy of this item for testing and my fair and honest evaluation. Of course receiving something for free may impact any review, but I can honestly say this is a solid product and worth the cost listed here. I have delayed my review a bit simply because I wanted to see if I would actually use and benefit from this Speaker. It has served its purpose on several occasions. I have used it in my office both as a charger and speaker. Packaging - shipped in solid packaging that was padded well, there is no way this should be damaged in shipping. Comes with the charging cable and a cloth bag for carrying and keeping from dust. Ease of setup - Charged it for the recommended time of two hours and easily got 8-10 hours of use before recharging. Powered up and started the pairing process, which connected without a hitch on the first try. Have not had any issues connecting via bluetooth at any point. I have not figured out the NFC option, but I am confident that is user error, and not really necessary. Buttons/Features - Has power, phone, play/pause, and volume or track buttons. I will say that everything works as advertised, but remembering the button combination to make things work takes a little bit of a learning curve. It is as simple as pressing or long pressing combinations, but if I had a complaint, I wish that I didnt have to think before pressing, but not a deal breaker. I like the ability to answer my phone while listening to music. This comes in handy when at the office and having hands free talking that seems to be clear enough. The sound through the speaker for calls is plenty clear, and nobody has complained when I have used this method to talk with them. Sound Quality - This is not a surround sound experience, and sound at maximum volumes isn't as rich as a high dollar audio system. (I have edited this portion of the review) The speaker is surprisingly loud, and I have yet to have a need to turn the sound all the way upother than for testing. All of my testing has been done with an LG G3 phone connected to the speaker, and a Asus Chromebook. I would rate the sound quality a 4 of 5 considering the size and a 3 - 5 if I was just rating pure sound quality regardless of price. I think it is important to consider what you are using. If I wanted a high dollar sound system, I would not be buying this device. For the market of portable bluetooth speakers I would say the sound quality is very good. Use as a Power Bank - I think this is probably the feature that has me most interested in buying a second unit. When at my office, my desk is small and the compact speaker size is great, add the sound from that compact space and the device is solid. Add to it that I can give my phone a fast charge when needed is a nice bonus. The manual also claims that you can connect more than one speaker together. I have a feeling I will be buying a second speaker to keep at home so this one can stay at my office. I will test this out and edit the review if I do end up buying a second one. I also will get a video review posted as time allows and after using it for a little longer. Overall, this is a quality device. I have bought a few other Sharkk products and so far I have not had any issues with their products. If you are looking for a speaker that is compact, practical, and provides powerful sound this is a worthy option. I use in a small office and a large living room and the sound fills the room well.

product_title: Zune HD Video MP3 Player
review_headline: Zune HD - Best for music lovers!
review_body:
First I have to say that I am in Wow land. This Zune HD interface was designed to make discovering music fun. Swipe your finger tip up and down to scroll the text menu up and down. Select music, and tap into your favorite playlist. Tap play and start playing the playlist. Okay, easy enough but it gets very fun, read ahead see what I mean.

Swipe down to the Radio. Add stations. If you hear a song you like, on the radio, add it to your cart. That's right, add a song you head on the RADIO to your cart. Hit the home button on the bottom to quickly escape the radio. Swipe down to Marketplace, select Cart, and the song you heard on the radio is in the cart. Download it and add it to your permanent collection.

It get better. You can do this wirelessly because of the built in WiFi. Now, Sync your Zune HD wirelessly back to the PC to push the song you just downloaded to your PC. How awesome is that. Your Zune Pass Subscription means you can grab all the songs you want.

Now, it gets even better.

On your Zune HD, go to the Marketplace, and start to tap on songs. You can play them through your wireless WiFi. Okay? Songs you don't even have, you can play right off the market place via WiFi. Think about that for second. If you are home and on your WiFi network, you can listen to any of millions of songs, without downloading them!!

Okay, say you find one you really like. Download it. It's all part of your Zune Pass.

I have not even scratched the surface.

QuickPick

That text menu on the home screen? It's one of two menus on the home screen. Swipe to the left on that text. See how there is this small strip of icons on the left side. They become in focus and the large text shrinks off to the right. Now, this little list of icons is huge. Swipe up and down and cruise through the history of the songs you have been playing. Even the radio station you set is here in this history. This strip also contains a QuickPick. So what is a QuickPick?

Say you are listening to song and you love it. You just found it on Marketplace and you want to listen to it over and over again until you're tired of it. How to find it easily? Well, tap and hold the album icon while the song is playing. A prompt window will appear and offer to pin the song into QuickPicks.

As you explore for music on the radio or the Marketplace, completely wireless, you can easily find those songs again via the QuickPicks or History. That's what that little strip of icons are on the left side of the home screen. Fantastic huh?

More fun stuff

So I am listening to song and I see the album cover on the display. Tap that screen, and the album dims. A new dimension of menu overlays the album. It's a control surface. You see pause / play in the center. Up and Down are volume up and down. Left and Right are skip left or right. The upper top is to go back. Ignore it for second and it goes away returning the album art to view.

The album / song you're playing has a small list under it. That's the songs coming up next! Tap on that little list and your in the list that this song comes from. You can now easily switch to other songs in this list.

All of these menus and animated and fluid. It's actually fun to run around within this interface discovering music, adding it to quick picks and retrieving it. It's almost like a dance.

Subscription music with the Zune Pass is such a great idea. And it really works with a device like this. Imagine all the ways to discover music, but keep the cost of enjoying all that music to a minimum. That's what the Zune accomplishes.

There is so much more. Audible Books works with this. Though you do have to download Audible's Download Manager. I've listened to well over 200 books over the life of my Audible subscription.

The Zune Marketplace software for the PC almost mirrors the features ofthe phone in that you can see your quick picks. You have a dashboard that shows you what's going on in your music world. And it gets this information from the device as well. As you add music, the whole ego system gets smarter and exposes you to more music you'll probably like. Absolutely fantastic.

Think about it. You can add hundreds of songs a month if you like. Listen to them via radio, and download what you like. Listen live off the Marketplace from your PC or even your Zune portable. What ever you do with the Zune HD will sync back to the PC. In fact, there's more!! I know huh....

So you have Zune software on your office PC too, okay... Listen to this. Go to Settings, Account, Subscription History. Remember, do this on your office PC, not your home PC so you really understand what's about to happen. Those songs you found on the radio, added to cart, and downloaded from the Marketplace are here in this history list even though this office PC had nothing to do with that. It's connected to your account so it knows. And you can, from your work PC, now download those songs to your work PC collection. It's subscription! You can have multiple PCs all connected to your account and they each aware of a collective history of subscribed to music. You don't have to carry songs with you on a thumb drive from your home PC to your office PC. Just let the Zune software show you the history. It tells you what is in your collection on that machine and what is not so you can update your office PC with those great songs you found on the radio or in the marketplace.

Hey, do you like Tina Fey's 3rd rock? I sure do. You can download those TV shows as video and watch them on the Zune HD. They have movies too. For rent in SD and HD. I'm watching 21 grams.

I have all the free games microsoft added to the apps section. By the way, you can download these from WiFi direct to the device! I've been playing Texas Hold'em.

With WiFi, you can use the built in browser to browse web sites. I have The Wall Street Journal, Engadget, PCWorld and several other favorites sites programmed into mine.

So, absolutely the best music experience you're ever going to have, because you won't have to worry about money while you download your ears off. Get the Zune Pass and just go crazy. Play games if you like that. Watch TV shows, movies, and music videos. Add your own photos too! Listen to Audible Books. I'm listening to the new John Twelve Hawks 3rd in the-part series of the 4th realm trilogy called The Golden City. Book one is The Traveler. You're missing out if you've never heard of it. I am also listening to Dan Brown's sequel The Lost Symbol. And actually, a Gunslinger / Dark Tower Stephen King book as well. Too much good stuff all came at once and I had to.

On the radio station I added, I found Black Eyed Peas - I Gotta Feeling. Oh I love this song! Also just found Cassie - Let's Get Crazy. It's amazing all that you can explore and find when you pay a flat rate and can go nuts like this. I'm in music nirvana.

This is so much better than any iPod / pay as you go eco system I've had in the past. I'm giddy and had to share. I'm bobbing my head to the beat of I Gotta Feeling. The bass is great! Oh that reminds me. The music quality is absolutely here!! If you saw me listening to my Zune, you'd know I was having a good time.

Okay, so enough. I have music to dance around to now.

Thanks Amazon for getting this to me on opening day. LOVE IT!!!!!it gets this information from the device as well. review_headline: Too pricy for the value, though I enjoy it everyday
review_body: I listen to this music system almost everyday - not only because the sound quality is so superior but also because my ipod touch connects to wifi and I can play iradio, pandora and other music streaming sites. Though it is superior to any other docking station I came across, it doesn't justify $300 price tag. One could choose comparable sony music system for much less price. So, I take out 1 point for the hefty price tag. Second, equlizer adjustments are badly missing. Few simple rock/pop/classic adjustments would have been added. Though I can change it in my ipod touch, I dont like changing settings in ipod touch for each song I play. I wanted that feature in the music system's remote control. For the price I paid, I think it is a genuine expectation. So, I take out another point. And 3/5 is just fair to the fact that I enjoy listening to it everyday.

product_title: Altec Lansing M604 Powered Audio System for Zune
review_body: This is REALLY great. It sounds similar to my husband's Bose. He has an Ipod, I have a Zune. The sound is crisp and clear and has great base. I bought 2!

review_headline: Works great w/ 2012 Mac Book Pro that dual-boots OS X & Windows 7
review_body: I use this cable to connect to a DLP projector and it works great every time. I use it with my 2012 Mac Book Pro which dual-boots OS X and Windows 7 64-bit and it never fails on either OS.

product_title: Apple Earbuds for All iPod Models and Digital Audio Players
review_body:
I bought these from Apple, and I msut say they are jsut GREAT!
Pros:
-Almost-noise cancelling, when off you can still ahve convorsations.
-Comfertable fit! And it comes in Medium, LArge, and small sizes!
-Strong cord.
Cons:
-Hard to get used to at first
-sometimes you ahve to really push hard to get them in

Really, that's it! I prefer them A LOT over the base earphones. In all, these are a great edition for ANY iPod or msuic lsitening device! :D

product_title: Creative Zen Vision: M 30 GB MP3 and Video Player
review_body: Better sound and picture than the IPod. Easy to download songs, pictures and video. All that and $70 cheaper.

product_title: Creative Zen Mozaic Series MP3 Player
review_body: We've purchased many Zen products over the years and we like the small size and usebility of this model. The battery life is ridiculously long, MUCH better than the larger Zen M's but that's good because the only way to charge this little one is thru the USB (unless you purchase the charger extra I think). Zen's have been good products for us in general but they definitely have a shelf life. We don't handle them rough but accidents do happen so maybe it's that they've been dropped a certain way but each one just suddenly has stopped working at one point and it's been futile to troubleshoot it or reinstall the firmware. It's been frustrating and we are hopeful the Mosaics will last longer than the M's. We are not big users of the firmware for creating playlists and we would probably have an easier time if we learned how to use the software more effectively. But that's our own fault, not Creative's. My recommendation is that if you can get away with the smaller GB model like this 4gb Mosaic, the price and all it's other positive features makes it the perfect little Mp3. Would definitely buy another one if we were looking.

product_title: JBL Balboa 10 Two-Way 5-Inch Bookshelf Speakers (Pair) (Discontinued by Manufacturer)
review_body:
I was excited to get these speakers and planned to add them to my system as a pair of back speakers to complement to two studio monitors and mid-size two-way speakers from Acoustic Research. I planned to drive them through my vintage Pioneer integrated amp.

With all the power needed, I hooked up the speakers. They are very easy to connect - either with plain wire ends or connectors, simply thread the finger-nuts down tight and the speakers are connected with color-coded terminals.

The front grills remove easily and snap back on positively.

The black cabinets will go well with most systems.

In short a good looking speaker that's easy to connect, and small enough to place in a number of locations.

I turned on my amp and started playing a favorite CD. I'm sorry to say that the speakers were not pleasing to my ears. Keep in mind that speaker \\"sound\\" is subjective. I have Infinity Reference series speakers in my cars, Acoustic Research studio monitors in my house (the old \\"real\\" AR speakers), and Bose system for the \\"good\\" TV in the family room. The sound I like is no doubt tied to my habit of listening to these speakers.

I found the JBL Balboa to be hollow sounding. While crisp and clean, they are overly loud in the mid-range. The bass wasn't as solid as my other speakers.

These are good speakers for low volume-level listening and would probably work as an element in a low- or mid-level surround-sound system as speakers for secondary sound. But placed in the middle of a high-end stereo system they were out of place. They're a good value for the price but don't expect to \\"Wow\\" anyone with them.

product_title: Beats Solo HD On-Ear Headphone
review_body: What can I say! so far it seems as though I's making my grandchildren happy because this item was purchased for my granddaughter. She looooooves them!! I'm glad I could make her happy.

review_body: Works Great. No problems. Just plugged it in and it did it's job. Now my TV is connected to my computer and I can use it as both a computer screen and a TV by just switching from HDMI to TV on the remote control SOURCE button.

review_body: The sound from this thing is amazing. The base is rich and room-filling. On several occasions I've used it with the provided adapter connected to a laptop. After about 10 used, the adapter stopped working. When I tried to pair it to the device, the speaker would just turn off. I've performed this within the auto-turn-off time frame. I don't know if I am missing something and reading manual doesn't help. I am still happy with it on use with a smartphone but wish that connection to the pc still works.
