product_title: Speakman Icon Anystream High Pressure Adjustable Shower Head
review_headline: Just spend the money -- it's worth it.
review_body:
I had a basic-model Speakman in the 1990s. It was all brass, solid as a rock, simple in design and function, and probably cost about $30 at the time I purchased it. The thing would probably be still working for me, but I tossed it into garage storage when I remodeled the bathroom, and opted for a high-priced, oh-so-fancy, multi-jet shower head from a company I won't mention. When that supposedly indestructible shower head needed to be replaced due to water streaming out the side seam (!), I looked around for my old Speakman. Gone. Probably donated to Goodwill by accident. So I went online and looked for a basic Speakman. Plastic! They are all plastic now. Then I saw this baby, and I was smitten. Old-school quality, even if it does come at a new-age price. I am pleased as can be after installing and using it. The overall design could not be cleaner, the chrome plating is thick and has a gorgeous gloss, the handle moves smoothly and evenly to move through the range of flow. I love the fine spray for most washing, while the "pour" setting is great for rinsing hair. No snazzy bells and whistles here, just a good, solid shower head that should last many years.

I think the reviewers complaining of inadequate water pressure may be talking about low water volume, which is a different issue. The strength of the spray this provides is quite good for a low-flow unit. I live in California, where every drop counts.

(One nice little detail is that Speakman provides the pipe tape necessary for installation, so don't buy any here, as I did.)

review_body:
I love this lighting system. It makes me giggle because I had two men (an electrician and my husband) tell me that I couldn't have what I wanted for under cabinet lighting and this system gave it to me with the least amount of work and destruction. I wanted a regular light switch to turn them on (one on each side of the room was acceptable), and despite one side of cabinets being broken up by a window, I wanted those to come on with one switch too. The problem is that I have a two story house. They said that holes would need to be punched through the ceiling and the electrician said that we'd need to be concerned about the total load. Fortunately we were making this decision before tiling the back splash so we were able to run the connection, under the window and behind the wall, without any major destruction.

One piece of advice I'd offer is to be certain you know whether you want the cool bright light system or the warm lights. Newer appliances, like my exhaust hood, use the brighter blue light leds and the lights we've all been using in our homes are more like the \\"warm\\" lights. If you mix lights, chances are that the difference will scream out at you, and/or the \\"bright\\" lights will feel too harsh.

I should probably tell you that I purchased this same system through their online store. We needed additional pieces that this kit doesn't include and so it made more sense to buy it direct. We had to run one wire behind the wall for the cabinets separate by a window and the company offers that wire on their site. However, I did buy additional connectors through Amazon. It might be helpful to know that the website has videos that were very helpful in aiding us with our decisions, as well as helping us know what to expect. IMO, this company is tops for those looking to update lighting with ease, at a reasonable price that is actually relatively inexpensive when compared to others.

product_title: Cook'n Recipe Organizer Version 10
review_body:
I have been using Cook'n since version 7. It is an easy program to learn and use with lots of options. I live in Australia so the measures are metric rather than imperial. Last year I lost a good deal of data (includinging my personal recipe files) from a failed computer. This SHOULD have taught me a lesson.

When I upgraded to Version 10, I had difficulties restoring my databases. This is not the fault of Cook'n, rather my own lack of diligence with backing up data appropriately. I have to start from scratch AGAIN with my Cook'n. Some recipes are lost forever I feel but maybe I have learnt with time to make appropriate backups.

Getting back to the program, it can be as simple or as complicated as you like. I do not use menus or indeed shopping lists most of the time but I still come back to Cook'n for its ease of use and flexibility.

The only beef I have with Cook'n is the printing side of things. As I am in Australia, paper sizes are not the same as the US but with a little tweaking, I can get around that. More printing options would be nice but that's on the wishlist.

I must say that DVO's customer service is great. I lost my purchased cookbooks but the DVO team were able to resend me what ones they could considering that I purchased them over 4 years ago. What book they couldn't send me, they offered a free download of any book I liked. All this done in a matter of 2 short days and only a couple of emails. Thanks Ryan, you are a legend and a lifesaver.

product_title: Adobe Premiere Elements 10
review_headline: Does NOT Make HD Movies for Legacy Players
review_body:
I have used five generations of Adobe Premiere, all the way back to version 1.5. While it is still a good editor with some strong features, the latest version, PE 10 flagrantly misrepresents its capability. It states on the box \\"Burn Blu-ray quality HD movies using standard DVD discs and burners.\\" This statement is under the heading \\"Share videos...with friends wherever they are\\". The problem is that your friends will have to buy a new \\"1080 HD DVD Player\\" in order to take advantage of this feature. Adobe does not specify that their new feature requires new hardware and therefore it is misleading and caused me to waste a good deal of time trying to find an explanation on their website. Not to mention that the claim that it works with any HD video camera is simply not true. It worked with my older camcorders, but not my new Sony.
On the other hand, the software does a fine job of basic editing and is particularly good at rendering discs because it has good control over the menu text and icon placement and has an excellent DVD preview screen so you don't have to burn DVDs to know if your menus launch the scenes correctly. Rendering to all formats is impressively fast and the Win 7 64 bit implementation is robust and only crashes occasionally.
More problems with PE are caused by Adobe's strategy to attempt to persuade users to use this product as the nexus of all their stored video and still media. Anybody who is serious about video editing will have a host of programs including viewers, converters and other editors. PE's cumbersome attempt to grab all the media files results in screens popping up unexpectedly that take you out of the core editing experience. This was never the case in the older products. Bad product direction for serious video editors. Also bothersome are their frequent attempts to pull users into using the related suite of Photoshop products, no doubt because they are losing market share to Picasa and other free photo editing programs.
This product is now no better than the Cyberlink competitor and the only reason I remain an Adobe user is that I am familiar with their menus.

review_body: Can't imagine doing taxes without it. Have been using TaxCut for years and ordered the same version on autopilot. Doh. Moved to FL last year. Not much use for the state vesrions in FL! Oh Well.

When calling QuickBooks customer support, you're calling India phonebanks and holding on the phone for 1.5 hrs or more until a live voice is heard. Aatrix customer support, while informative and patient, requires the same long wait times. Both lines feature \\"hold\\" music that is guaranteed to give you a bad hair day and re-cycles frequently. Recommendation for a much better accounting product: MYOB

Bernie Krause, PhD

Numbers is the weakest point of the iWork suite. As far as I can tell, there is no text-to-columns function. I tend to drop down to perl or perl + SQL for heavy math, so other missing functions don't bother me. The lack of text-to-columns makes importing data from a SQL query or the command line harder than it needs to be.

Still, iWork is a great value. I'm glad I bought it, and recommend it to anyone with a mac.

product_title: Poser Pro [OLD VERSION]
review_headline: Quality OK for Freeware, but not for a $500 Product!
review_body: Review of Smith Micro's Poser Pro Well, at this juncture I've been working almost daily with this product, and thought it was high time I shared some of my impressions with other prospective customers/victims. First of all, as a long-time software professional, I am quite aware of the complexities associated with 3D rendering, and the high demand on processing resources -- both memory and CPU. Even though I'm running a fairly capable machine (quad-core, 64-bit, 8Gig of ram, 2 - 1-terrabyte drives, Win XP-64, etc.), I am prepared to accept that complex 3D scene rendering will take some time. That said, what I DO NOT accept is the necessity for the program to outright refuse to render, or even LOAD some scenes, reporting \\"not enough memory to load texture map'! In software engineering terminology, this just indicates sloppy memory management. Even after researching the issues, tweaking the render settings, running a 3rd-party memory management utility -- the problem persists. Perhaps even harder to excuse is the generally brittle nature of the package. It regularly becomes necessary to resort to ctl-alt-del, bring up the program manager, find the process, and use the \\"kill process tree\\" command to get rid of the hung application, and then start the whole process over from the start, often losing work in the process. Then, of course, there are the incessant \\"An unexpected exception occurred: -50\\" messages. Once again, ctrl-alt-del, etc., is the only way to proceed. Don't even bother looking in the event manager, or searching for a log that might explain the source of the problem. The Poser \\"engineers\\" apparently considered such niceties as superfluous. Interestingly, it's often possible (and necessary) to load a scene that Poser Pro refuses to accept by using Poser 7! I can then eliminate some elements, save the file, and reload back into Poser Pro. Did someone decide it was necessary to introduce some additional bugs into the flagship package.? Ialso have a strong suspicion that the program suffers from some severe memory leaks. If you monitor memory usage, you'll see that, regardless of the nature of the scene, memory usage just keeps on increasing, until, inevitably -- that's right: ctrl-alt-del. The thing that amazes me most, is the proliferation of gushing reviews of this shoddy piece of . . . programming. Are the reviewers on Smith Micro's payroll? Have they done any more with it than render a quick naked woman, gawk over it, and then write: \\"WOW, what a GREAT product!\\"? There are, of course, so many other annoying quirks as to defy enumeration here. Suffice it to say, that this is an extremely irritating program with which to work. Smith Micro touts this as a \\"professional package,\\" an utterly absurd assertion. It's quality is such that I might overlook the bugs in a freeware package, but certainly not in something costing nearly five-hundred bucks. Oh well, there's a sucker born every minute. Now, as someone who has watched my own company's profits eroded by software piracy, I am generally opposed to such abuses, however, in cases like this, my advice is to acquire the product from someplace like Emule, or Vuse, or other torrent servers, use it for a while, and if you still think it's worth the asking price, then by all means, write that check. Otherwise, just use it at a cost that's precisely what it's worth: $0.

product_title: Rack 2 Filer V5.0
review_headline: Pretty and easy but proprietary database is not so great idea
review_body: Received with ScanSnap S1500. Goods: 1. Relatively easy to use and organize without having to use windows file system. Good for the non-computer geek who just wants to get rid of the paper but have a things organized in binders and folders. Others: 1. To attempt to minimize software piracy (I don't blame them) there is a relatively complex installation which failed in my case on several attempts. Support helped me get around this problem within a few days and were very helpful and responsive. But, if I ever need to reinstall or move to another computer (if you are scanning your life aren't you going to take it with you to the next computer?) I can expect it to be difficult. 2. The main problem with this program is the proprietary database. The file and folder naming structure in windows is not representative of what you called the files and folders in the program when you scanned them (unlike the default program that comes with the scanner). This mean that you need to use the program to find the files and if you ever no longer have this program or access to it (see number 1 above or if you are using Windows 10 ten years from now and this program is no longer supportable), all your scanning work will be for naught and you will have a bunch of folders and files with gobledegook for names. Good luck finding that birth certificate then!

product_title: Power PDF Standard, Bilingual English/French
review_headline: Less Bloated Acrobat Replacement, but Quirks
review_body:
I've used Nuance Paperport pro V12 and the bundled PDF program for a while on an older XP computer (soon to be retired).

Power PDF is a significant step up that adds form creation, OCR features, conversion to/from PDF from lots of document formats, and adds a version of Dragon for adding notes to PDF's. It is at it's heart a PDF converter.

Installation was completely uneventful. The registration/activation is a bit annoying but it seems the sort of the way the software world is headed. This hasn't always been the case for Nuance products. Paperport in particular was known for installation problems.

Like most Nuance products I've used this has a quirkyness to its interface. If you have used other Nuance programs you'll know what I mean. If not you'll either get used to it or become frustrated. I think most people adapt without much trouble.

In general I've used the PDF conversion features and some basic form creation so far. I've played a little with the dragon notes and it seems to work pretty well with my voice.

The results seem to open on fine on Acrobat Reader XI and Acrobat Pro X..

Power PDF installed and worked well. It has a broad set of features. The interface is Nuance "quirky" and the registration/activation is a bit annoying. So I'm giving 4 stars to Power PDF.

Hope this helps someone.

product_title: Quicken Starter Edition 2013
review_body:
I wanted something basic and simple just to use for balancing my checkbook. I didn't want all the online banking stuff.
Once I figured out how to bypass all the online features the program is ok. I wish it had an option that it would show you upcoming bills in my startup menu whenever I turn on my desktop. I got spoiled with Microsoft money, wish they still made that software. They could have made this program a bit simpler, but it'll do.

product_title: Quicken Home & Business 2013
review_headline: Don't do it!!! Wait for the bug revisions - R11 still not it.
review_body:
I admit it, I got excited for the new version and upgraded. Nearly all the marketing features hyped above are not ready for prime time. Budgeting is a big fail. I'm going to revert to an excel spreadsheet and manually transfer the values. The numbers are off and there is an odd way of handling categories and future transactions.

Mobile sync crashes around 50% of the time and takes roughly 5 minutes to complete, while the software is locked and unusable. I hit sync and walk away. Using the iOS interface took some getting used to, and I may use it \\"on the fly\\" but it's not as nimble as the Pocket Quicken app in the days of Palm (yes, I'm that old and have been using Quicken that long!)

I could go on, but the other reviews hit the high points. I came from 2011 and wish that I could go back, but I've put too much new info in the data file, so I'm stuck.

If I could do it all over again, I'd wait to upgrade until users report all the kinks are worked out (if ever). Just head over to the forums and see what people are posting. I wish I did before I purchased. As of today (10/8/12) I have taken a step backward from usage. Thank god for Excel to fill in the holes while other people that purchased this too early \\"beta test\\" for Intuit.

---------------------------------------
EDIT 11/15/12: I just downloaded the seventh (R7) update and it completely corrupted my data. Mind you, I had to add a \\"balancer\\" transaction to a few of my accounts with the upgrade to 2013. Amounts were off, but I couldn't figure out where or why.

With R7, I had to restore from a backup (thank God I backup). If I could downgrade this review to zero stars I would. I no longer attempt to use the budgeting feature, we use excel and manually patch the data back into Quicken. I have mobile completely disabled (it added corrupt data). I bought a book to understand some of the \\"new features,\\" if only to find a workaround.

If I could go back to my previous version or if there was a reasonable competitor I would abandon this product immediately.

--------------
EDIT 3/2/2013
--------------

We're on R11 (patch 11) now. I'm happy to report that I haven't had any data corruptions recently--for a couple of months. The mobile/iOS experience is still not working. Now every time I try to use it recently I get a \\"Data Error\\" and it boots me completely out. That is to say it requires that I go back an re-enter my UN and PW as opposed to simply the iOS program PIN. Then it simply gives the same error and requires a sign out. I may delete the account and create a new one, again, to see if that fixes it as it has in the past. As you can gather from my review above and other users, it hasn't been sufficiently reliable for me to consistently use it, so I can't say it's a huge loss for me. However, if you view it as a big selling point, don't purchase this software for this feature.

There are many bugs that are still not worked out (again, venture over to Quicken's support forum). My view on the software is still the same. This is not an adequately vetted program and is still not ready for public release. If you MUST upgrade for some reason, such as banking compatibility, it's tolerable--at least you won't lose data (well, maybe). I still backup frequently. The only reason I'd say that's a remotely acceptable option is because there are no real competitors here. My rating stands at 1 of 5 stars.

Highly recommended.

product_title: Dragon NaturallySpeaking Premium 11 [Old Version]
review_headline: Will Not Work on My Windows 7 Computer
review_body:
I installed this today and after a few hours, tons of searching for a solution online, and plenty of messing with my computer settings, I am throwing the towel in. I continually get an error message that the "Sound Level is Too Low" and I cannot even get past the profile setup wizard due to this error. The headphones included with the software are either junk, or the software itself has an error with Windows 7. A user forum I was reading mentioned that if you call Nuance with this problem they will spend plenty of time making sure you checked all the obvious solutions, then they apologize and tell you they have a software glitch they are working on. I haven't subjected myself to this process, and I don't plan on it, either. No product should require this much work just to get it to function adequately.

Well, a glitch working with Windows 7 is a big deal. I am computer savvy, I can build a PC from parts, I can install software, I can change system settings in Control Panel, and I can troubleshoot simple problems better than most computer users. I checked every single listed solution I was able to try, and I simply cannot get this software to run properly. If this is a known bug, as it seems to be, then this product should not be sold as compliant with Windows 7. I am returning this, there is no way I plan on spending even more time and effort getting this to work. I checked the microphone function with the Windows Sound Recorder, and while it is a bit low, it records just fine. So, either the issue is the included headset (hopefully Nuance is not hair-brained enough to send out a faulty headset that will make their software look like garbage) -or- the problem is that their software is buggy and doesn't run properly on my new, clean, non-buggy computer.

product_title: Autodesk Sketchbook Pro 2011
review_headline: Easy to use somewhat powerful paint program that will help turn you into a pretty good digital artist if u are not already one
review_body:
I loved this product. It's a paint/photo program, not a drawing program. Adobe Photoshop (AP) is a paint/photo program; Adobe Illustrator (AI) is a drawing program. AP creates bitmap files, and AI create vector files. Bitmap files are images made up of little dots. Whereas vector files are mathematical formulas that are easily scaleable. The native files for Sketchbook are stored in layered TIF format, but they can be exported in many different bitmap file formats: gif, jpeg, and PSD.

I have used quite a number of different kinds of computer applications over the years: wordprocessing, spreadsheet, presentations, database, email, WYSIWYG Web page designers, paint/photo, and drawing. Of all these different types of computer programs I have had the most difficulty learning to use well the paint/photo kind. This is probably because I am not really an artist - at least not one adept at creating visual pictures using my hands. I am much better at taking photos with a digital camera and tweeking them using Adobe Photoshop. I have always found AP to be a tough cookie when it comes to creating original artwork from scratch.

Sketchbook Pro makes it much easier for me to create original artwork from scratch. It is designed to be used with a digital pen tablet. The intuitive user interface is slick and pleasing to eye, and you will be up and running in no time using pencils, brushes, layering, and pan/zoom features. This product is going to make it easy for you to \\"sketch\\" out a rough draft of the artwork you want to create. It will not create a masterpiece probably, but you can certainly move your file into AP and tweek your art to your heart's content.

This product was easy for me to install, and it has never appeared sluggish to me when using it. I suppose the only problem I had with the product is its name. I think of the word \\"sketch\\" as being a drawing. Thus at first I thought this was a drawing program. So don't be confused by the name. What you will get with this product is an easy to use somewhat powerful paint/photo program that will help turn you into a pretty good digital artist if you are not already one. And if you are already expert I suspect you will thoroughly enjoy this product to create the early-goings of a paint file you will fine tune in AP. 5 stars!this product is an easy to use somewhat powerful paint/photo program that will help turn you into a pretty good digital artist if you are not already one. And if you are already expert I suspect you will thoroughly enjoy this product to create the early-goings of a paint file you will fine tune in AP. 5 stars!

To make matters worse, EMC will want to charge you $69 if you need help with this indecipherable mess. I only hope that the Time Machine backup feature that debuts with Mac's Leopard version of OS X will finally put this product out of business.

product_title: Mac OS X 10.1 [OLD VERSION]
review_body:
Mac OS 10.1, the long-awaited gift from Apple, is impressively stable. The stability of this OS gives it an edge over the older build of Mac OS 9 (and older systems). Dynamic memory allocation and preemptive multitasking are positive aspects too.
However, I would not suggest OS X on a G3 unless you are ready for slow resizing and tediously long launch times.
Indeed, even though it is slower, I feel that I am obliged to use OS X on my 600 MHz iBook - not because Apple is phasing out "classic" support. The only thing that truly binds me to OS X is that it is much more stable than OS 9. However, seeing how good things are coming with the new ideas from Apple as they update the system, I would suggest keeping an eye open. Perhaps OS X will speed up soon.

product_title: Adobe Acrobat X Standard
review_headline: Licensing Nightmare - Avoid at all Costs
review_body: We have several copies of this installed in our office. There are about 12 licenses installed on various machines. Over time, as machines break down and get replaced you lose a license for each one. You could deactivate the license to free it up, but this is impossible if the machine won't boot or you take it apart before remembering to deactivate. To make matters worse, we have no idea which keys are install on which machines. I guess Abode expects you to track this, but I can't figure out how to retrieve the installed keys. This is a business, I don't know what the guy before me did. So, now we get to call Adobe everytime we need to use one of our licenses and they do not have the greatest support team. This has cost us plenty in productivity and the product isn't cheap to begin with. If you can avoid using this product I would recommend doing so.

I even had to contact Microsoft support for a small glitch and they remotely controlled my pc and fixed the issue - for free. Windows 8, and since I've updated to 8.1, is far superior to Vista. I have Windows 7 on another computer and really like it too, but Windows 8 is so much more stable and fast compared to Vista it's not funny. Just be aware that you will need to re-install many if not all programs after the upgrade. There is a free Windows 8 "are you ready for Windows 8" download you can get for free before you buy. Best software purchase I've made in years.

review_body: I bought this software for myself (learning keyboard) but I also have children. The software focuses on learning how to read music and also locating the notes on the keyboard. It would be helpful for children/adults playing any instrument. Most of the lessons are based on learning the notes on the scale, counting beats, etc. Cons: The doodle pad composer does not save on my computer (I have vista) so when my son makes his \\"masterpieces\\" I can not save them to listen to later. Also the graphics are very dated. There doesn't seem to be any competition for this type of software so I guess that is why it hasn't been updated. product_title: DietPower - Top-Rated Calorie Counter, Nutrient Tracker, Weight Loss and Diet Software
review_headline: Wonderful tool to assist you on your way
review_body: I don't believe this is for sale anymore on Amazon (although you can buy from DietPower directly) however I first discovered this software by looking on Amazon. I'm so happy I did! I started a \\"diet\\" a month before I discovered this and was putting in a lot of exercise and moderately watching what I ate but not getting great results. I had lost a couple pounds but nothing near where I should have been for as much hard work as I was putting into exercise and strength training. I went to the DietPower website and downloaded a two week trial version for free. In those two weeks I lost five pounds simply because I had visibility to the calories I was taking in and what I was burning off through exercise. The software itself is rather complex but it is very simple to use. Logging foods and exercise is very easy and quick. It even helps you track your water intake based on demands from food and exercise. It helps track the nutrition in what you are eating so you have visibility to how much vitamins you intake and where you might be lacking throughout the day. This is great software. I would highly encourage anyone, even those maintaining weight, to go grab a trial version of this and try it out. This software has shown me that I can eat well and still achieve results.

review_body: I purchased this because I liked the idea of having an encyclopedia set without taking up the space. When I recieved the software I did a full install, got to the screen offering the trial for Britanica Online and felt dooped. The software is extremely basic, for further information they want you to purchase the online access. This may be good software for elementary kids research for school, or general information browsing but definitely not for info junkies. The navigation of info and articles is strange, the atlas is very basic maps, the search function and results are cluttered and frustrating. There are very few user preferences that you can change. Overall I don't feel it was worth the $22 I paid for it. I would maybe purchase as a gift for someone without internet access, other than that I would pass. Would happily build shelves for a whole set instead.

product_title: Norton 360 5.0 Sop 10 User
review_body:
Norton doesn't work and you will be expected to pay $99 to get Customer Support when the program fails. I am very computer literate and relied on Norton to protect my computer from viruses and malware. I am quite competent at avoiding threats, but there are some that even the most experienced user can't prevent. Their program did not catch an old \\"virus\\" (technically malware) that has been out for a long time, so it wasn't an unavoidable problem.

When I contacted customer support for help removing the program Norton didn't catch, they tried to charge me $99 to correct their mistake before they would even discuss the problem (either do it yourself or pay $99). I spent over 4 hours working with inexperienced techs that did not have adequate computer knowledge trying to get the problem fixed. The \\"Customer Service\\" agent deleted at least one unrelated program from my computer (was not infected) that I will have to pay to replace. I will now have to spend my time trying to figure out how to totally remove the malware from my computer as it seems to be in the registry and affecting my computer after Norton's software claimed it was quarantined (it took 4 hours and 3 techs to even get that far on top of the multiple scans I had run). I will likely have to pay someone to work on my computer to ensure that my computer is safe and pay for new antivirus software. My computer is nearly unusable.

Bottom line, Windows 7 has great antivirus software built in (you do have to find it and turn it on) or you can use a number of free options that work as well or better than Norton. It has been years since I've tried Mcafee so I can't comment on it's effectiveness. Do not depend on Norton even if you are computer literate. If you aren't knowledgeable about the latest threats or if other family members that aren't use it, you DEFINITELY don't want to rely on Norton.

product_title: PERRLA for APA
review_body: Going back to school after 23 years was really terrifying. I had never heard of APA guidlines and format. When I looked at the APA guide book provided by the college, I had a full blown panic attack. First ever! APA just did not make since. PERRLA was recommended by three coworkers who had receintly graduated from college. PERRLA is amazing. I have completed my first semester without even one APA error. It makes paper writing a breeze. Step by step instruction for every paper. PERRLA saves all citations so previously used sources do not have to be re-cited. Saves hours of time for each paper. I had one technical difficulty (My own error). I emailed PERRLA support and recieved a reply with step by step instruction the same afternoon AND on a WEEKEND! The support response was easy to understand and solved my problem instantly. It was written as if the person was speaking directly to me. Contact numbers were provided as well. PERRLA has taken the stress out of paper writing. Love it! Old Dog With New Tricks! Candy Rutledge RN

product_title: ACT! 2005 [Old Version]
review_body:
My problems began with installation.

1.) File was corrupted upon loading the software from the CD. Went to ACT website, they had the file available (not a unique problem, obviously), and I was then able to load.

2.) I then had problems converting data from ACT! 6.0. Went to ACT website again, only solution was to uninstall and reinstall. I also shut down Spybot, which may have corrupted the first loading. They tell you to shut down Anti-Virus software, which I did, but not Spybot. Data converted after doing this.

3.) I have NO custom fields, but data from my Salutation field did not convert. All fields blank. Since I had converted to ACT! 6.0 from a previous customer manager, this meant I lost all my contact first names, and this was the deal-breaker. I may have been able to get through this, but see 4.).

4.) I did not notice item three for several hours, and used the program during that time. As previous reviewers have noted, it is noticably slower than ACT! 6.0. It also slows down the rest of one's computer, reboot is slower, etc. I also started having problems with MS Outlook crashing, which had never happened before.

All things considered, I decided to return the software, and stick with ACT! 6.0, at least for a year or so while they figure things out. ACT chose to go with a more complex platform, which may help them with their corporate accounts, but is more problematic for smaller users. Computer speed will continue to be an issue. Also, you cannot synch with other users with Windows XP any longer. You must upgrade to Windows Professional.

I found ACT! (Best Software) to be good about trying to make things work, and allowing me to return the software. Their support group surpasses their product development group. If you are dying to try ACT! 2005, either wait a few months while they fix a few things, or be prepared for a tedious conversion process and slowerperformance. Buy from Amazon or Best Software or a reputable vendor directly, so you can return the software if necessary.

product_title: NTI Backup Now 5 Advanced Edition DVD Case
review_body:
I was surprised to see that NTI Backup Now 5.5 advanced has such low ratings, so I came here to read the reviews. I see two different 1 star reviews from people who say nothing about its backup/restore performance, and instead complain about their installation issues.

I am no expert in this area. All I can say is that I chose NTI 5.5 Advanced because I needed a program that wouldn't balk at backing up OPEN FILES. And so far, 5.5 seems to be doing that just fine. So far I have not had a need to restore any backups, so I am reluctant to give this product my full endorsement until I've seen whether it restores properly. So I'm going to give it three stars for now.

But come on people, just because you're having install issues, don't automatically assume its NTI's fault. My install went smooth as silk and I've been using the product for many months with massive (50+ gig) automatic backups every night. I've tried a few similar products. This one seems to be pretty easy to use for an average Joe. And it does backup open files.

product_title: Chess Tactics ART 3.0
review_body:
In this review, I consider 3 points

1) organization and difficulty of the material
2) interface
3) software vs book (M. Block \\"The art of combination in chess\\")

1) The soft is marketed to players with elo up to 2300. At the same time, the material is classified according to tactical and geometric motives. This has both pros and cons, and IMHO suits better to beginners and lower itermediates rather than to more advanced intermediates and experts. A book cannot be organized both ways; a software certainly makes it possible, but no such feature (e.g. @show a random position with a difficulty between 50 to 120) exists in CT-ART (even in the test mode, the topic is still shown in the upper bar).

The difficulty varies dramatically throughout the course. Comparing with well known Konotop series of tests in chess tactics, difficulty level of 10 should belong to \\"test for beginners\\" (ca 800-1200 elo), while problems with difficulty above 110 would probably be found in \\"tests for candidate masters\\" (2000 FIDE Elo and above).

2) interface: fair to poor. First of all, if you have windows Vista you need to know a thing or two about the interactions of this soft with your OS. Convecta recommends turning the UCA off, which is plain ridiculous, because ct-art also works fine (if it ever works fine) when you install it in a separate folder outside your \\"program files\\" folder. Secondly, I never succeeded in making the pieces move faster and the intervals shorter (the pieces move extremely slow. If the problem is easy I nearly fall asleep). Theoretically you can control the speed and the interval, but in practice the soft doesnt respond: thisngs move the same slow way whatever speed you set. If you make a mistake, the program displays a refutation if it typed in. Otherwise, it shows a \\"prompt\\" using ridiculous blinking markers. I had to quit the excersise and restart it each time I made a mistake. You CAN turn them off though, this option does work.

3) CT-ART vs Bloch's book. What is good in CT-ART? The very selection of the problems. I do find it excellent, it teaches precision and consideration of all tactical motives in each position. But: here the soft and the book are nearly identical. What is bad in CT-ART? Basically, everything else. Poor interface. ridiculous ratings that have nothing to do with the reality. In many positions there are several ways to win, but the program gives you a penalty (tipically, the first move is unique, but on later stages.... Once I got a penalty for correctly executed checkmate in one!). On the other hand, when solving a difficult problem (90+) I happened to fail to find the principle ideas, but still collect 60% of points for that problem! Conclusion: I quit the soft and got the book.

UDP: Now CT-ART is already available with the new Peshk@ interface. As far as I was told, the interface issues have been resolved.

Hope this hepls.
AVoption does work.

product_title: Macromedia Dreamweaver MX 2004 [OLD VERSION]
review_body: Ditto to everything "arryman" said below. I am an Art Director and I recently upgraded from version 3. The older versions were built extremely well and I liked Dreamweaver, because it was one of the few WYSIWIG web design tools that did not "mess up my code." This new version runs very, very slowly, inserts code in "wrong" places, adds redundant and unneeded tags and crashes in the middle of doing all that! I like the interface and obviously the support for CSS, but I've been finding myself hand-coding in "Code" mode, and not really taking advantage of the WYSIWIG tools.

review_body: I had thought that Microsoft might have been the creme of the crop, but it seems that it's just that: a myth. This software feels very empty, counterintuitive, and hard to use. The \\"points of interest\\" lack plenty of places that I needed to find during my travels. The address search is pitiful, and I just could not think of a good reason of why I bought this. I'm guessing that getting a high class compilation of maps and GPS is better than just a maps. Please save yourself some money, and invest it in something like a TomTom GPS + maps.

product_title: Quicken 2003 Premier Home & Business
review_body:
Last year Quicken Home and Business made a $12,000 error in the balance reports for my tax return. We found this error ourselves during an audit. When we requested a fix from Intuit, the reponse from The Office of the President at Intuit was, \\"Sure it's a bug, but Quicken is sold AS IS with NO WARRANTY. We don't guarantee that our software does anything at all, so we're under no obligation to do anything to help you. We will, however, give you a 5% discount on the upgrade, which *might* fix the problem.\\" (Yes, that's 5%, not 50%)
My recommendation: if you need a reliable accounting package for a small business, look elsewhere.

product_title: BackUp MyPC
review_headline: BackUp My Pc is everything it is advertised to be........
review_body:
I was looking for a back up program that would work with Windows XP Home. I did my homework by searching and checking out all the available back up programs on the internet. I also checked to see if my RW and CD and ScanDisk drivers were listed in the compatable drive section of their website. After having downloaded a trial copy from Stomp website I found that it worked perfectly with my computer and system. I then ordered the software from Amazon.com and it works just great. No trouble downloading and preforming a complete back up of my hard drive. I backed up 11.3 GB in 4 hrs. and 30 minutes which took 17 cd's for the 87,393 files. This time also included the formating of the CD's and the verifying of the data. Not a single error.
I can recommend it highly that is if your cdrw and hard drive and other drives are compatable.
Tom McCallie

review_body: Do not waste your money on this version or any other packaged version that includes CDs with it. If you have a computer, access to the Internet and can type, you need not spend your money buying this product. The only thing worthwhile in this is the basic Family Tree Maker software. Everything else that is in this package, and more, can be found on ancestry.com!!

product_title: Quicken Essentials for Mac
review_body:
I've been a Quicken user for nearly 20 years, and have loved it. However, this Quicken Essentials for Mac program is the WORST. It does not provide even a quarter of the previous version's capabilities, which is absolutely incredible. I've never seen a worse \\"upgrade.\\"

And the worst part about it is.... I'm STUCK! I can't go back to the previous version, because the data won't follow me. It can't be exported for use in any other software, include Quicken 2007 (which is still for sale).

My recommendation... don't buy it. And let Intuit know what a tremendous damage they've done to their reputation. I am now to the point of looking for alternative vendors - and once I switch, it may well be another 20 years before I look back.

product_title: Nova Development US Hallmark Premium Blank 4x8 Photo Cards
review_body: I have the Hallmark Greeting Card software and these cards were perfect for the Christmas Cards I sent to Family and Friends. Inserting the picture and printing could not have been easier. The big plus is the money I saved by using these cards. Excellent Quality.

product_title: Mac OS X Snow Leopard Family Pack (5-User)
review_headline: Snow Leopard is NOT ready for prime-time. Do NOT upgrade!
review_body: In short: Snow Leopard (SL) feels like a Beta release. It is NOT ready for prime-time. This honestly feels like the release of Microsoft Me (Millenium edition, remember when MS put out that garbage as an \\"upgrade\\" to '98?). SL is THAT bad. Details: With every update to OS X you hear the stories of third-party apps not being compatible and causing issues. Understandable, given the limitations of some (especially smaller) developers. In my case, the apps in question are Apple's own Mail and iTunes. Specifically, Mail would lock while trying to download new mail. The update circle/arrow next to each email address would spin all day. Meanwhile, the same mail came through just fine on my wife's MacBook Pro (running 10.5.8). iTunes would at some point (while sitting idle all day while I'm off at work) inform me that my iTunes library could not be found and the pop-up error messages (one for each of the thousands of items in my iTunes library) could not be Force Quit. After rebooting, everything would work fine for a while. This is why I switched to a Mac. To avoid this exact issue (rebooting multiple times a day just to do the basics). I upgraded my iMac (just over a year old, Intel Core 2 Duo 2.4) to SL on 9/3 and gave it a week to sort out any issues. Last night I threw in the towel and reverted back to Leopard (this is why you MUST create a cloned copy of your hard drive before you upgrade (use Super Duper or Carbon Copy Cloner and create a bootable drive (and test it! (hold down the Option key while you reboot)) before you do any OS upgrade (PC or Mac))). Time Machine couldn't save me. It told me I was out of disk space (I wasn't). I know all the great features Apple put into SL (which I why I upgraded so early in the life-cycle) and was loving them (smart disk eject, click and hold on an app in the Dock and see all the occurences of that app, super fast boot times, etc). But until the bugs get fixed, I don't dare go near Microsoft Me - sorry,I meant Snow Leopard - again. Apple, shame on you for putting out this garbage as a gold master. You were a month ahead of schedule and still rushed the QA. And it shows. No longer will I be able to say \\"get a Mac, it just works\\". I've put many friends into Macs over the years. Now I just can't recommend them without a huge caveat. Not until Apple makes this right. Well, Apple... we're waiting....

I tried the new version since I now have Vista. It is no better. Although it promises to work with Outlook, it apparently doesn't work with Microsoft Outlook Exchange. Every time I try to sync it just crashes. There is no customer support unless you are willing to pay their ridiculous prices. I've got seven years of data in there but I am ready to abandon it and re-enter the data in another program. Stay away. Intuit should be ashamed of themselves.

product_title: Fluenz French 1+2+3+4+5 for Mac, PC, iPhone, iPad & Android Phones, Version 3
review_body:
I have a general working knowledge of several languages - studied in high school and college and through living and working in various countries - but have never formally studied French and knew very little of it. I've been looking for years for a suitable program for it but have always shied away from the \\"total immersion\\" approach of Rosetta Stone. From my, albeit limited, exposure to Rosetta, it seems that their lessons leave too many unsolved questions about what's going on. To follow them, you'd really need to equip yourself with a grammar book and dictionary and be prepared to dig for lots of explanations the lessons don't supply.

The theory behind an immersion program seems to be that little children learn languages much better than adults, so we should try to mimic that experience with adults. The trouble is that adults don't learn as little children do - and as the Fluenz creators recognize, that's both a plus and a minus. It's a disadvantage in that adults will most likely never master a language quite as deeply as a child. An English-speaking adult who learns French, for example,will never be able to speak French without at least a trace of an English accent. But having learned English thoroughly before learning French is also a huge advantage! English speaking adults can leverage their existing knowledge of how a language (English) works to learn the target language. As adult English speakers, we already understand the many forms we need a verb to take: for I, you, s/he, we, they. So when we learn the \\"I\\" form, we look for the \\"he\\" form and etc. Because of the knowledge we have of what we don't know, we make much more rapid progress in the target language than a child could.

But. We can do so only if we are given explanations that correspond to the questions we naturally have. For a simple example: we naturally wonder, why do you say you are going \\"en France\\" but \\"a Paris\\"? It's unnecessarily frustrating if the language program youuse never bothers to provide you with the simple explanation that you always use \\"a\\" when you are going to a city but not necessarily to a country.

Each Fluenz lesson begins with a short intro, then goes to a dialogue which provides information and vocabulary relevant to tourists. Each lesson develops and expands upon the grammar introduced in the previous lessons. Because most people traveling to Francophone countries will be interested in getting the basics down, lessons often center on being in a cafe and ordering food, or with traveling from place to place or asking questions at a hotel. These short dialogues can be listened to with no subtitles, with subtitles only in French, and with subtitles in English and French. After the student has listened to the dialogue, the instructor comes on and goes through what the student has just heard, line by line, adding additional relevant information as well as mnemonic devices to help students retain the information. The instructor also adds related concepts or structures to those introduced in the dialogue. Subsequent \\"workouts\\" encourage students to practice through reading, writing, listening and speaking. What I find particularly delightful are the little comments the instructor sprinkles in along the way about some element from film or sports or culture. Once, the instructor mentioned that the bidet was \\"one of France's great gifts to womankind.\\" I doubt I'll ever forget that line as it was so unexpected and human a remark.

As much as I love this program, I would have given it 4.75 stars rather than 5 if that were possible because the software is just a bit glitchy. You have to play around with it in order to get it to work properly. For example, you might, in a given workout, get just one question and find, when you hit \\"next\\" that the workout seems to be done. There is no way to move forward within it. What you need to do in that case is select \\"next workout\\" and then go back - and backwards -until you complete the previous workout. It took a while for me to realize this, so I missed some valuable practice along the way.

Overall, Fluenz is an excellent program, long overdue. I look forward to learning my next language with Fluenz.

product_title: The Invincible Iron Man: The Complete Collection
review_headline: Amazing value at the original price
review_body:
This collection consists of actual comic books that have been individually scanned and converted to PDF files. This is one of a number of such collections, all of which were an absolutely amazing value when they were first published, with hundreds of comic books, some dating back to the 1960s, available on a single DVD for one low price. Unfortunately, Marvel Comics refused to continue licensing their content to Git Corp and the collections are no longer available. Today, the DVDs are collector's items, sometimes going for hundreds of dollars. At their original publishing price, this was an incredible deal. At the prices today, when you can even find them, you should definitely think twice.

The files are not DRM (Digital Rights Management) protected, so you can copy the PDF files to your computer or laptop, even to your Kindle Fire tablet. You can also create backup DVDs to make sure that your collection always remains accessible. If you view the collections on your computer or laptop, using the Adobe official PDF viewer, everything is fine. If you view the collections on your Kindle Fire tablet, there is a semi-transparent "Marvel" watermark that will show up on every page. I've tried every PDF viewer in the Amazon App Store, including the Adobe PDF app, and they all exhibit this flaw. Once I got used to it, though, it didn't bother me much and it's handy to have a really portable way to read these files.

Each file contains one complete comic book, including the front and back covers, all of the advertisements, the letters page, and so on. The files are arranged in two-page spreads, 1100 pixels wide by 850 pixels high. I can reduce these to roughly 75% of full size and still read them. Much below that and the text becomes hard to read and the details are muddy.

For the collections that go back to the 60s and 70s, it's both nostalgic and hilarious to read some of the advertisements (Sea Monkeys! X-Ray Specs! Charles Atlas!). The scan quality in those earlier issues is surprisingly good, considering the age of each comic book. These are very readable, in very good condition.

This collection begins in 1963 with Tales of Suspense #39 (for 12 cents!) where Iron Man was first introduced. In 1964, in Tales of Suspense #59, Captain America joined Iron Man and the comic title officially became Tales of Suspense featuring Iron Man and Captain America. This continued until 1968, where issue #99 became the final Tales of Suspense issue and each hero subsequently got his own title. The Iron Man title continued through issue 332, in 1996, after which Marvel rebooted the character and restarted the issue numbering. The reboot concluded in 1997 with issue #13, with a second reboot beginning in 1998 and ending in 2004 with issue #89. There was a third reboot in 2005 and the collection concludes with issue #12 of that reboot, in 2006. In addition, the collection contains Annuals 1 through 15, Annuals 1998 through 2001, Giant-Size Iron Man #1 (from 1975), and a detailed Iron Man bio. All told, counting index files, there are 586 files to browse.The scan quality in those earlier issues is surprisingly good, considering the age of each comic book. These are very readable, in very good condition.

This collection begins in 1963 with Tales of Suspense #39 (for 12 cents!) where Iron Man was first introduced. In 1964, in Tales of Suspense #59, Captain America joined Iron Man and the comic title officially became Tales of Suspense featuring Iron Man and Captain America. This continued until 1968, where issue #99 became the final Tales of Suspense issue and each hero subsequently got his own title. The Iron Man title continued through issue 332, in 1996, after which Marvel rebooted the character and restarted the issue numbering. The reboot concluded in 1997 with issue #13, with a second reboot beginning in 1998 and ending in 2004 with issue #89. There was a third reboot in 2005 and the collection concludes with issue #12 of that reboot, in 2006. In addition, the collection contains Annuals 1 through 15, Annuals 1998 through 2001, Giant-Size Iron Man #1 (from 1975), and a detailed Iron Man bio. All told, counting index files, there are 586 files to browse.

review_body: I bought this program for my wife who is a choir director and has a degree in music. Me, well all I can play is the radio. The work around was to call tech support and get files from them to complete a multi-step process that took 3 days.
