We have no problems with crashing or videos/content that didn't load or play properly. We plan to do many more courses with youth digital.

product_title: Quicken 2008 Premier [OLD VERSION]
review_body:
(This is a drastically revised review. My initial installation experience was good, and I rated the program 5 stars. Now I rate it at 1-star.) Here's the recap.

I dreaded the upgrade from Quicken 2005 to 2008. I waited as long as possible, then validated my data, etc., and set aside a day when I thought I could stand the frustration. Whaddaya know, the installation went pretty easily, and soon I was up and running, intact, or so I thought. I use Quicken BillPay and have for years, and I have Windows XP Pro. My online billing proceeded normally, and I was greatly relieved. I even submitted a 5-star review. The program does little more than Quicken 2005 did, but the new eye-candy was pleasant, and the upgrade was mandatory. By waiting as long as possible to install, the program was already on Version 7 (God help early adopters!)

Then I noticed that my checking account appeared as \\"Wachovia Securities\\" when the correct account was and always has been \\"Wells Fargo\\". I tried all the obvious ways to fix it, and nothing worked, so I thought I'd give the new \\"chat\\" support a try. When it became clear that the things the support person suggested wouldn't work, she simply disconnected!! That solved HER problem. And I decided not to sweat it, since the erroneous name didn't seem to cause any other problems.

But then -- I pulled up an old saved report from Q2005, and one column of data was garbage. This time I tried email support. Through an exchange of emails, they advised me to validate the file, and if that didn't work, to supervalidate it. I did all of that (very carefully, I had a backup, but by the way the normal backup you get is worthless, more on that), and it still didn't work. The email guy said I should phone in and talk to a support person.

AND THEN I noticed that the validation process had ELIMINATED ALL RECORD OF ONLINE TRANSACTIONS AND ALL OF MY ONLINE PAYEE LIST, which was substantial!! Oh woe. This is when I tried restoring a backup file I'd made the day before. But get this: WHEN QUICKEN 2008 MESSES UP, IT DOES SO IN A WAY THAT PREVENTS YOU FROM GOING BACK TO A PREVIOUSLY FUNCTIONAL VERSION. Every old file I \\"restored\\" now showed the same total absence of online transactions and onlinei payees. Now I did decide to phone in for support.

I was pleasantly surprised: Without a long wait time, I was connected to a young woman in Bangladesh or some other remote location, but she was really really sharp and actually solved the problem. This was not trivial. I had to cancel my online billing setup, validate and revalidate and revalidate the file until no \\"corrected errors\\" showed up, and then reinstate online billing. We basically took Quicken apart and put it back together again. She also corrected the account so that Wells Fargo showed up instead of Wachovia, although this was separate from the issue that had wiped out my online transactions. As far as the column of garbage in the saved Q2005 report, she said that Q2008 does that sometimes; I should just delete the report and recreate it. All these problems were solved, my online payee list was restored, and at that point, I was charged $24.95 for the call. I tried to argue that Q2008 had created the problem and corrupted my file, but decided to blow it off and just pay and be done with it. I thought my problems were over. Ha.

BECAUSE THEN, when I next \\"updated\\" my online accounts, Quicken Bill Pay downloaded the LAST TWO YEARS OF TRANSACTIONS, roughly 650, along with a few new ones interspersed. The balance in my checking accounted was now -$87,000. That's MINUS $87,000.

In the next call to phone support I found out that \\"That's just how it is\\". I would have to go through the last 2 years of transactions and manually delete the duplicates. (He did tell me to sort the account by \\"most recently entered\\" instead of by \\"date\\", so I was able to select groups and delete with only 1-2 clicks per transaction instead of the 4-5 clicks it normally takes to delete a transaction.) At the end of all this, my accounts have been somehow \\"unreconciled\\" -- all records of the last month's reconciliation have been eliminated. So I'm having to redo that too. I don't actually expect my bank account to balance at the end of all this (How do you carefully and thoughtfully delete duplicate records when you're feeling like !@#%$?) I plan to just enter a fudge factor and forget about it.

Here's some learnings: If you're converting from an old version, and you decide to validate the file before you start the conversion, keep rerunning the validation routine until it turns up no more error messages. They don't tell you this, but the sharp woman said that was important. Then you may or may not want to \\"super-validate\\" which you do by holding down the shift key while you go thru the validation procedure.

Then you can pray a lot. If your bank account name comes up wrong, try ignoring it. If your old reports look funny, delete and recreate them. Do anything you can to avoid using the Q2008 version of validation.

If you need support, go immediately for the phone support. I talked to 2 people, and both knew what they were doing. The first woman was awesome (except for not telling me the horrors that would happen the next time I ran the online update). The second person, a guy, knew I was, well, screwed, and he tried to be as nice as possible about it. I have used Quicken since 1998, and I will say that support is better than it was a few years ago (not close to the way it was Back in the Day), and they don't charge you unless they solve the problem. The chat and email support were useless.

All for now.a transaction.) At the end of all this, my accounts have been somehow \\"unreconciled\\" -- all records of the last month's reconciliation have been eliminated. So I'm having to redo that too. I don't actually expect my bank account to balance at the end of all this (How do you carefully and thoughtfully delete duplicate records when you're feeling like !@#%$?) I plan to just enter a fudge factor and forget about it. Here's some learnings: If you're converting from an old version, and you decide to validate the file before you start the conversion, keep rerunning the validation routine until it turns up no more error messages. They don't tell you this, but the sharp woman said that was important. Then you may or may not want to \\"super-validate\\" which you do by holding down the shift key while you go thru the validation procedure. Then you can pray a lot. If your bank account name comes up wrong, try ignoring it. If your old reports look funny, delete and recreate them. Do anything you can to avoid using the Q2008 version of validation. If you need support, go immediately for the phone support. I talked to 2 people, and both knew what they were doing. The first woman was awesome (except for not telling me the horrors that would happen the next time I ran the online update). The second person, a guy, knew I was, well, screwed, and he tried to be as nice as possible about it. I have used Quicken since 1998, and I will say that support is better than it was a few years ago (not close to the way it was Back in the Day), and they don't charge you unless they solve the problem. The chat and email support were useless. All for now.

product_title: VMware Fusion 2 [OLD VERSION]
review_headline: Not perfect yet, but getting there
review_body:
I've been a Parallels user for some time and at the moment still use Parallels for a Windows XP installation.

When VMWare Fusion first came out I had downloaded it, not because I was unhappy with Parallels, but because I needed to run an OS that Parallels couldn't install but that I knew worked under VMWare on other platforms.

That OS is SCO Unix - I still have a handful of SCO customers left (just a handful, fortunately) so from time to time I need to access a SCO box to remind myself how something works or to test something before I inflict it upon my customer.

As I hoped, VMWare installed and ran SCO perfectly. Well, almost - I still haven't got the mouse to work in the GUI but for my purposes I really don't need that - I can always vnc in if need be. I did have a little trouble getting the network to work - I wanted it to dhcp but it wouldn't, so I finally just gave it a hard address and all was fine.

As it happened, the next day I needed to test something on the latest Centos so I installed that under VMWare rather than Parallels and of course that was 100% perfect - no issues whatsoever.

I see that VMWare now has the ability to convert a Parallels install.. I haven't done that yet, but really, why should I run both of these?

And Parallels does seem to be a very busy boopy - I happened to be running \\"opensnoop\\" and noticed that Parallels has a LOT of activity.. I noticed nothing from Fusion during that same period. Now Parallels was running Windows and Fusion was doing Centos, so it might be Windows fault, but I would guess VMWare is going to be more efficient if it isn't already. I think they've just had more experience and resources.

I've read many reviews that show Fusion as faster - and I do notice that my XP is slow.. of course XP is often sluggish anyway, but I think I'll be doing that conversion soon.

product_title: Webroot SecureAnywhere Internet Security Plus 2013 - 3 Devices
review_body: I bought this from Amazon for about $19 incl shipping. It got to me by regular mail 4 days after I placed my order. $19/3 computers = $6.33 per machine for internet security. I previously tested all the major competitor's products in real time for 30 days each. Some passed a lot of malware, some bogged the computer down, some interfered with my e-mail and some allowed viruses to pass. I have run real-time tests with malware scanners and sandboxes on my machines. Of the several products I tested, this one has come closer to a perfect score than the others. My malware scanners come up with zero malware now most of the time and the competing products always passed some each day. This product is the least invasive of any other - meaning it doesn't bother me with pop-ups at all and doesn't slow my computers down. I worry less about malare and viruses now and enjoy my computer time most using this product. It auto-scans each day unnoticed. If I use the scan button, it takes less than 2 min to do a full scan. Add the fact that I got it so cheaply and fast, then I have something to be very happy about. How would I rank the competition? #2 Norton. (it's almost as good), like all the competition the scans take quite awhile. #3 Kaspersky - doesn't bog the machine badly but passes malware. #4 BitDefender - heavy program, does the A-V job effectively, passess malware, uses noticeable computer power. #5 ESET - not a resource-heavy program but I didn't test it as heavily as the rest but it gave me no real problems that I recall. AVG- best of all the free ones. Panda- it passed a Trojan to my machine. IOLO AV, crashes and needs re-install fairly often - I had it for a year. Very weak AV. Trend Micro - About as good as IOLO, maybe slightly better.

product_title: Microsoft Windows 8 Pro - Upgrade [Old Version]
review_body:
I bought this product in October 2012 and it never seemed to work correctly. Later, I found that it needed \\"activation\\". When I very carefully entered the 25 character product key, the program rejected it and refused to activate the program. By the time I got around to this the product was not returnable at Amazon.com and I was forced, by Amazon, to contact Microsoft for a fix.

The Microsoft phone number initially offered by Amazon was incorrect. The second number offered by Amazon got through to a dispatcher who issued a service ID and was transferring me to a technical representative. That line was disconnected during the wait. I called Microsoft again with the ID and was told there would be a 19-35 minute wait. I insisted. Eventually, a representative verified that my original product key was valid, even though it wouldn't activate my software. She issued a new product key that worked and which eliminated the assorted problems experienced with the software.

If you buy this Microsoft software:

1. Failure to activate the software causes strange and unattributed problems.

2. ===> BEWARE THAT THE PROVIDED ACTIVATION KEY MAY NOT WORK! <====

3. If you don't act quickly, Amazon won't be of much help.

4. Getting service from Microsoft is a painful and time-consuming task.

The cost of time wasted would have paid the differential cost in moving to a Macintosh system. There's no future for a company who can't even do activation properly!

product_title: Quicken Home & Business 2011
review_headline: Wasted Money, Fails to Work With My Bank DESPITE Promises
review_body:
Wasted Money, Fails to Work With My Bank DESPITE Direct Promise that it does.

Their support guys just told me after a few hours of troubleshooting: \\"yeah, we say we support your bank, but it won't work for you. Sorry, we can't help you.\\"

Such unethical and untested capabilities should not be present in financial products. This is the first time I bought and tried using Quicken and it WILL NOT HAPPEN AGAIN.

Please try to somehow make SURE that it works with your financial institution before buying it - do NOT trust their website with a list supported banks. Their support will go thru their checklists and then say \\"sorry!\\"

TEMPLATES, TEMPLATES, TEMPLATES

Have you ever found yourself wondering how to present information for that important business topic, or homework assignment in either a presentation or a white paper? SMARTDRAW WILL MAKE YOU STAND OUT IN FRONT OF THE CROWD - With almost no effort or time on your part!

Smartdraw BLOWS AWAY other software competition by providing an exhaustive number of templates for almost ANY professional or educational assignment. I ran into Smartdraw about 2 years ago - and now it is the FIRST place that I go ANY time that I have to communicate anything to clients, work colleagues, or school assignments.

I rely on it for use in literally 100% of all of my presentations, client business proposals, or business planning and development needs. My wife just received her MBA, and she also used it routinely in most of her class assignments.

The ease of finding the PERFECT Template, form, or work tool is AMAZING to me - and requires literally NO effort to clip into your Powerpoint presentation.

Smartdraw is the most essential software product that I have ever used! Any doubts? Download a 30 day trial at the Smartdraw homepage - and you will be amazed as well!

product_title: SAT/ACT/PSAT
review_headline: Totally helped me to raise my score!
review_body: My first SAT and ACT scores were not good enough to get me into my first choice college. A friend had recommended this after her scores went up so I bought it. It was like having a private tutor helping me through the whole test. I loved the advice that it gave on test strategies, and the flash cards made it easy to remember the new things I was learning. The best part was the practice test which allowed me to see the areas that I could work on immediately and told me how to complete each problem correctly. I could take a small portion of the test at a time, save it, and come back to finish it later. If you want to boost your score for the SAT or ACT get this computer program now. It was easy to use and made studying fun. Plus I know that the strategies this taught me will help me excel on any test. Without this I would be going to a local state U, not my first choice school. Thank you for creating this; it really works!

product_title: Parallels Desktop 3.0 for Mac - Old Version
review_headline: Near Perfect With Boop Camp Partition
review_body: I bought Parallels for Mac because of previous problems with other similar program, VM Ware. In all fairness, the VM product was a beta so I should have guessed it would be buggy, but even the non beta version had its fair share of bugs. Although VM Ware loaded XP home without a hitch, using the program was fraught with difficulties. First, it was slow as molasses in January. Im not taking just a little slow, Im talking go to lunch and maybe itll be finished slow. Secondly, it was prone to mouse failure. Although it would recognize my mouse, it was always at least 2 inches off the mark. If I wanted to click a box I finally learned to position my mouse at least 2 inches below the intended button and then click. Finally, VM Ware allows for the import of an existing Boot Camp partition (see below) but the process is slow and one slight misstep spells doom. For the novice, its intimidating. Then I went to Boot Camp, which is Apples built in Windows capable utility. It worked without a hitch but you had to reboot to either OS X or Windows and hold the option key to get a boot menu. Of note, Boot Camp runs Windows natively, that is, at the same speed as a regular Windows machine. Fact is, it runs quicker on a Mac! All you have to do is go to the Boot Camp utility (under Utilities in the HD icon) and it walks you through it. I got Parallels because I was tired of rebooting my computer to get to Windows. I use Quicken 2008 quite a bit and Quicken for Mac really bites so I do have to use Windows. With Parallels I dont have to reboot. How difficult is it to access the Boot Camp partition with Parallels? Well for starters, it takes about as long as reading this sentence. Once you install Windows into Boot Camp you then install Parallels in Mac. Upon opening Parallels the first time itll ask you if you want to import the Boot Camp partition with Windows on it. Click yes and youll get a desktop icon that states My Boot Camp. After afew minutes of tweaking youll have Windows running on your Mac desktop. Of course, its not all fun and games. For example, youll get a warning that your Windows serial number is no longer any good because of significant hardware changes on your computer. Not a problem. I called the Microsoft toll free number and they issued me a new serial number when I told them what happened. Also, until Parallels recognizes and installs your mouse in the window, youll have to revert to the old ALT routine (the underlined Y in Yes means you have to press the Y key to enter the command. Making things weird is that you sometimes have to hit the ALT or CTRL key, sometimes you dont. Go figure). Also, you must learn to read instructions. Your mouse cursor will be stuck in the Parallels window that appears. It will seem you cant get it out of the box. Read the bottom of the box and itll tell you to hit CTRL and ALT to get the cursor out of the box and back to Mac. It you go to full screen mode, youll have to remember to key in ALT and ENTER to access the Mac screen again (it merely minimizes the window that has XP or Vista in it). By the way, the default memory allocated to Parallels is 512 MB. Some may find this a tick slow and you can increase it to half of your available RAM if you desire (I have 4 GB so I could go to 2). I found 512 to be just about right, but Vista will require at least 1 GB. If done properly, Windows will act just as fast in Parallels on Mac as it does in Boot Camp. I could detect no discernible difference, but there are a couple things to remember: 1. If Windows is open in Parallels, shut it down as you would any Windows machine. Shutting it down by closing the window may make it crash. 2. Maximize the window for best performance. If you use the default window size things get really crowded very quickly. 3. Dont think you can get away using a hacked or cloned version of Windows. Parallels demands a serial number before it will load Windows, unless you import it from Boot Camp and then Windows asks for a serial number. Either way, youre out of luck if you attempt to use a fraudulent copy. For the price I paid (about $20 when I bought my Mac) you really cant lose with Parallels. It works as intended and actually runs Windows better than a Windows machine.

product_title: iLumina Bible Software - Gold Premium - Upgrade Edition
review_body: three of five disc are defective--need shipping return address thank-u david permenter

product_title: MAGIX Movie Edit Pro 18 MX Plus
review_headline: The Magix Pro That I Know
review_body: After using the Magix Pro series for the past 3 years, I had an opportunity to run some competing video editors, including Sony Vegas and Cyberdirector, to see if there would be any rendering advantages in other software formats. I discovered that the nomenclature of most video software these days is so different between programs, that it requires a complete retraining of processes in order to get results, which I found myself unwilling to do. The 'comfort' of the Magix interface, coupled with a good book-sized publication included in the package, made it a compelling choice for me to decide upon acquiring MX Pro 18. While its rendering times are not the fastest in the industry, the amount of video and audio tools included in the package (audio recordists take note, this is as good as Pro Tools for a computer multitrack solution!) make the program one of the most powerful in its price range.

product_title: Biblical Hebrew
review_headline: Information I wish was available before purchase
review_body:
There are a few things I wish I had known before I purchased this softwear.
The first and most important thing is that the hebrew font is very small in most screens.
Most of the screens have a hebrew font that is very very hard to read and
some of the vowels you just have to guess at.I cannot find any place to change
the size of the font in these windows.
The dictionary of hebrew words has an awfully small font.
Only on the \\"reading\\" screens can you enlarge the font.
There is a help menu but it did not \\"guide and direct\\" as much
as I would have liked.

The positives are that it is acessable night and day and for as long as you
want to study.
It is very colorful and engaging to look at.
The reviews on it are great...I am still looking for that greatness.[[ASIN:B000FXV25E Biblical Hebrew]]

product_title: Kaspersky Anti-Virus Personal 5.0
review_headline: Should be "KAV, ver. HAL 5.0 " (it wants to own your machine)
review_body:
I bought this sucker right here on Amazon because I too
had read the glowing reviews. I wanted to try something
other than McAfee and Norton and chose this. Had no
problem installing it, but it scans constantly
(and I have excluded many filetypes and folders from
scanning, with little improvement). It can take 5-6
hours to do a complete scan, and interferes with almost
every program I use. It has caused printer errors,
freezes my graphics program and always hangs the
computer when I shut it down.

Don't buy this headache! Phone support is non-existant
and email's go unanswered for several weeks (if they're
answered at all).

Install it and you've got yourself the \\"HAL Version\\"
of anti-virus programs (HAL--as in \\"2001,A Space Oddessy\\")
--it takes over your machine, slows it down to a crawl,
and can be a nightmare to uninstall. You've been warned!

product_title: Norton Antivirus 2012 - 1 User
review_body:
Yes, there are free windows sites you can go to that SAY they can and will protect your computer, but NOTHING works like NORTON. I have actually purchsed other products that \\"claim\\" that they can do what Norton does, but they cannot. Norton will actually WARN you if the site you are about to go on is dangerous for your computer. Norton runs it's own scans constantly, so you do NOTHING, but sit back, relax, and know that your computer is safe. Well worth the money, and if you are looking for Norton now, there is no place like Amazon to purchase it. You will find sellers with the lowest prices. I have purchased Norton two times now, for years 2010 and 2011, and will only look on Amazon when it is time for another one. A great product at a great price with the right seller.
Gayle Flores

While I recognize the prowess and legacy of microsoft os's in general, I wish by now they would stop ripping off their consumers for many-year-old software or even just software in general. I'm not criticizing the product so much as I'm criticizing Microsoft's bad (or good, depending on which cushy leather office chair glossed with the blood of the poor you're sitting in) extortion of the american public. Smart business, or squeezing us dry?

product_title: iLife '09 [OLD VERSION]
review_body: Ok, I love my iMac and am a huge fan of Apple products. So when I read the reviews of iLife '09 and found reputable sources writing that upgrading was a \\"no-brainer,\\" I put down my 70 bucks and bought the upgrade. The problem, for me, is this: The new features, such as guitar lessons in Garage Band and face recognition and GPS location tags for iPhoto don't add up to much. That is, I have found that I just don't use them. At all. I'm not claiming that this is a bad product--it isn't. I am suggesting, however, that the upgrade isn't significant from the perspective of users like me, who, busy with work and family, don't have much time any longer to practice guitar and who download home photos from the digital camera for storage and, in some cases, printing. Pretty basic applications. Any user who falls into the category of free-time-deprived basic user will probably regret spending the money for the upgrade.

product_title: Encyclopedia Britannica 2006 Ultimate Reference Suite Win/Mac DVD
review_headline: disappointed & it seems to slow my computer down
review_body: I had high hopes for this product. There is no doubt that the content is good , but accessing it is the problem. The full product takes over 4GB which is to be expected , but when it is loaded it really does slow my computer down & I don't have an old system. Also , it is not as quick as wikipedia. The recent debate about which is the better system is still running. Overall, I wld trust EB over the free system , but I do find the free wikipedia(sp?) easier to use & less of a burden on my computer. Overall , if you need a reference system I would find it hard to recommend. I have actually taken off my laptop as it really was 'boggin' every thing else down.

product_title: Microsoft Windows 7 Home Premium Upgrade [Old Version]
review_body: I have upgraded 3 different PCs and laptops running XP to 7 and it has been a worthwhile upgrade. The speed at which the upgrade completed is quite fast and the driver/hardware detection was seamless. The machines run as fast as ever with new functionality and better stability (XP was pretty good about that too, in all fairness). All in all, I have been very happy with the update: fast, stable, compatible, and cool. What more could one want?

My husband and I have spent hours trying to figure it out. A lot of the art is good but the program should be scrapped. Hallmark should never have put their name on this one.

product_title: Norton 360 Version 4.0 1 User-3 PC
review_headline: Do NOT buy this product, your computer will slow way down!
review_body: For all that is good in the world, do NOT get Norton 360. It will suck up your computer's resources, slow it down, and cause you eternal frustration. For example, it runs \\"background scans\\", meaning when the scan is running, it's in the \\"background\\" and is not supposed to affect the performance of your computer while you're working. NOT TRUE. For the 10 minutes or whatever it takes for the \\"background\\" scan to run, you're computer is so slow you effectively can't do anything. It's agonizing. Sure, you're supposed to be able to schedule the scans manually so you can run them when you want, but for whatever reason, the scans just keep running whenever they want. Also, when it is doing the \\"live update\\" to get the most recent virus info, it's the exact same thing. Agonizing slow death. And if you read around, I'm not the only one with this problem. Yes, it keeps your computer safer. Yes, it cleans up space on your hard drive. Because it does what it says it will do, I'm giving it 2 stars instead of just 1. I've had Norton Antivirus installed before and never had these problems.

product_title: QuickStart American Sign Language
review_body: This CD is great for people new to ASL or have little knowledge with sign language. The fact that you can watch the signs being performed at the same time you can read the text is awesome. Great CD for the price.

product_title: Retrospect Workgroup Backup 4.3 (20-user)
review_body: This is the easiest backup program that I have ever used. If you are looking for the best solution for backups, this product is for you. Highly Recommended!

product_title: Microsoft Office 365 University 4-year Subscription
review_body:
This review isn't for Office 365 itself, but rather for the University 4yr Academic Key Card version, which requires student validation.

I am a student who has used previous student versions of Microsoft Office. Therefore, I did not expect any issues with validating this product when I ordered it; however, I personally found the student validation process so frustrating, I stopped trying to install Office 365 and just started exporting Google Docs into Word format and turning in my assignments that way.

Since Microsoft is discounting this product for those in school, I can fully understand the need to verify that people who buy it are actually students. However, the verification process shouldn't feel like a waste of time and it shouldn't take more than a couple of minutes. As a student, I've purchased several software packages under an academic discount and this is the only one I've given up on. I think Microsoft should take a cue from Adobe and Apple and make their student software more accessible.

product_title: TurboTax Deluxe Federal + E-File + State 2012
review_headline: mostly the same, but in some ways it's worse
review_body:
I've used TurboTax to do my taxes for many years, in some years I used TaxCut (or whatever it's called now). I've generally found TT to be slightly better, but not dramatically so, and therefore have in the past recommended that buyers consider price as an important factor in the decision.

This year I'm in the position of being able to compare the Deluxe & Premier versions, and so far can comment in detail on the investment-related features, which is where they differ.

But first: if you're not familiar with TurboTax -- it really is a good option for preparing your taxes if you are a do-it-yourself person, comfortable with going to the IRS website or other tax info sources to get answers to questions. No, TT will NOT, despite the grand marketing claims, take care of you if you're not quite sure about the rules or are confused about some little tax detail that's not either simple or common.

If you aren't very comfortable with figuring out the rules, then you might want to have a tax advisor available who can answer questions and perhaps also review your return before you submit it.

Now to this year's program: it mostly looks the same as last year's, and the basic workflow seemed familiar and easy to follow. I do like the fact that you can either follow the easy guided path (EasyGuide) or navigate on your own. The dowload options for W2s and 1099s are comprehensive (you can find lists on the Intuit website), but note that Paychex is apparently (still) not supported.

1. If you have tax-exempt dividends from a multi-state muni fund, TT doesn't allow to enter the fraction or amount of the dividend that's from your state (so tax-exempt in your state return). They want you to split the 1099 into two parts, one for your state and one for the others. This is just DUMB. A product that generates $1.5 billion in revenue deserves a bit more care & attention.

2. This year you'll start seeing the complexity that the IRS created with the basis reporting on sales of stocks and mutual funds. The problem is that some sales are \\"covered\\", meaning that the basis has to be reported to the IRS (using your chosen basis method), and others are reported as sales, but basis is your job. I found that sorting through this stuff is mind-bending and error-prone, to a large extent because of the shockingly poor job TurboTax does at helping you work through this. A simple table-type structure where you could quickly enter, review, and correct all the transaction data isn't hard to imagine. But imagine is all you can do because of the horrible interface you'll get in TT. I even went into the Forms interfaces, looking at the imported 1099B and the 8949 and the Cap Gains Worksheet -- unfortunately it's even harder to work with those.

3. If you have investment transactions, you should probably cough up the extra money and get the Premier version. With the Deluxe version the security names & transaction descriptions are not downloaded correctly: For example, \\"1000 shares of XYZ\\" shows up as \\"EXCH to ABC\\" in my case with a 1099B. (Being cynical, I'm thinking that this is an intentional feature degrade, to \\"persuade\\" us to buy Premier.) With a 1099Div, the payer name was simply \\"Vanguard\\", instead of the name of the fund, which is not ideal because you want the name on the return to match the name on the report going to the IRS.

That's all I have for now, I'll try to write an update when I'm done with my taxes. Hope this helps!

Note (Jan 27):
I found another area where TT doesn't handle things well, but it's likely to be quite rare: I have a foreign bank account, which earned interest. I couldn't find an obvious place to enter (foreign) interest not reported on a 1099, so entered it in the 1099 workflow, filling in the required details. I had already generated a Form 1116 because of mutual fund foreign income. However, TT did not add the new data to the existing 1116, or generate a new one.. It only flagged this during the error check, and essentially said \\"you made a mistake, go do the form\\". Not what I expected.

Note (Feb 16):
Another funny thing: I downloaded Vanguard brokerage 1099, and it seems that only the first sale (capgain) transaction was imported. I can't tell easily whether this is a Vanguard glitch or a TT glitch. Either way, watch out for stuff like this seems to be the appropriate conclusion.w data to the existing 1116, or generate a new one.. It only flagged this during the error check, and essentially said \\"you made a mistake, go do the form\\". Not what I expected.

Note (Feb 16):
Another funny thing: I downloaded Vanguard brokerage 1099, and it seems that only the first sale (capgain) transaction was imported. I can't tell easily whether this is a Vanguard glitch or a TT glitch. Either way, watch out for stuff like this seems to be the appropriate conclusion.

product_title: Sony Vegas Movie Studio + DVD [OLD VERSION]
review_headline: not all its reviewed to be
review_body: i did my homework, read the reviews and happily went purchase the sony vegas movie maker + dvd. They are very nice features as advertised, and its priced great, thats the only reason i gave it any stars, but it is NOT user friendly. The manual is haphazzard and disorganized and the show me how feature is great if you already know what you want to do and what its called in this software, otherwise you're basically randomly pushing buttons. Which I dont mind personally, i like experimenting with software, but I never could get the program to capture audio. It will record audio, but my doing a voice over of \\"this is my baby saying her first word\\" is not quite the same as actually hearing her on the video. NO help from sony, I emailed 3 days ago with only a form reply saying we got your email and will reply as soon as we can, and the phone service, you have to pay for...up to and beyond the amount of service, no thanks. This time I think I'll listen to cnet rather than user reviews and return this and pick up the pinnacle. Even if it crashes or freezes, Im not getting anywhere anyway.

product_title: Microsoft Windows 7 Home Premium
review_body: I installed Windows 7 on my Mac using a Bootcamp partition. Now I can get more utility out of it.

product_title: Pinnacle Studio 9 [OLD VERSION]
review_body: I like my Pinnacle but it can be frustrating at times. I just had to learn some patience and take it slow. Let it do it's thing before you move on clicking away. I got lucky when my computer had a meltdown and I lost everything. I had a DVD of some of my work to see how it looked on the TV. It was only 11 minutes long and had several video clips with music and some transitions. I imported it from my file menu and used it as I continued working on my project. I re-rendered this project and it rendered very fast since all the parts of the this segment had already been pre-rendered. This gave me the idea to make my full movies with several DVD's like \\"Acts\\" in a play. I make a few minutes of my show with all the bells and whistles i want and then render that segment on a DVD R/W and do this until my show is finished. My Dad's Vietnam documentary was broke up into 6 different DVD's. I then import all of them and drag and drop them into my timeline and render the entire movie on one single DVD. If any small glitches exist i fix them but keep that to a dull roar! the whole idea is to keep the overall work load down to a minimum - like re-tracking some music or adding a transition etc... and then I render the entire project. My first disk on the documentary is 59 minutes long with lots of music, tons of video i took on my panasonic mini DV with a lot of transitions and effects. Since all of the segments of my disk were all PRE-RENDERED the whole project rendered very fast and did not CRASH!!! and this has worked on other projects for me as well. I have a Sony Vaio computer with Windows XP Home Edition Ver. 2002 with a Pentium 4 CPU 3.06 GHz - 1 Gig of RAM and 200 GB of Drive D space.I hope this helps others on their projects and good luck movie making.

product_title: Home Inventory Pro 2011
review_body: Difficult to get support service. After repeated attempts I have been unable to get any response through their support ticket service or customer service email. Other comments confirm that the program has a tendency to crash and that they fail to respond. If you 're creating a home inventory for insurance and similar purposes, and the the program crashes as this one does, then you will not have the information you need when required.

product_title: Adobe Photoshop Elements 9
review_headline: Ancient CD-ROM-Based Format with Junk Software on It
review_body: I wasted $70 hoping find a simple color filter to put over my pictures. This program has no color filter, no ease of use--all it functions are not right at its surface for total freedom to use right away: Every button you need to use has to be learned--and its particular location discovered, sometimes--by learning where the designer has hid away...Buddy: Anything you need on this program should be on its desktop window, just a cursor move and one click away: all these extra odd, hidden steps just to get the button to you need are deliberate programming hacks designed to cheat the cheaper program of its chance to do the job well enough to say, \\"Job done!\\" They want you to check in to whether Adobe's $200+ program--3X as expensive as this program--offers the hope you're looking for: paying Adobe more money to make its designers do a more considerate job meeting the customer's expectations: well, it's 2012, Folks, and simple picture editing Apps for tablet-like desktop layer app-button point-and-click accessibility are out there--so we can just forget about caring whether Adobe's designers care whether they are doing a better job with their programs, or not: the old Adobe CD-Rom era is dead! This Adobe program did not put the buttons on the desktop surface layer where we expect them!--So, don't buy it! Don't even bother with a try: These buttons need a desktop fix-it feature--total re-arragiblility of its buttons, so its buttons can be put up on the desktop layer where they belong: all in one place like a tablet does with it's Apps--Adobe's designers should have known make them movable there already--since Apple's I-Pad has been able to do this since mid 2010: I phones and the I Pad have had rotating carousel surfaces since then--if Adobe needed a desktop surface layer with more space.... Adobe also frustrated this product's usability by putting obscure symbols on the buttons: super-snazzy photo technician noise that just confuses the customer who hoped he would instantly know what to do with the program--just with one look--this Adobe's program can't let you re-name these buttons with regular words, so each time the customer goes back to this software, the memory of the user has to do the work of rediscovering how these strangely-symboled buttons worked last time they were used... These experiences with the product are enough to reject it and they are clearly designed to be part of it to get the disappointed customer to want to dump the cheap program for the next level program up in price--Once Adobe suckers you into buying this cheap one: you'll be on the treadmill for guessing if the next more expensive photo-editing program has all the expected feature for 3X the price!--where a reasoning man is hoping for at least 1/3 the defects, after paying 3X as much! But People, these problems are more easily corrected by spending $0 on Adobe!--that's right: Zero Money! Because Microsoft's picture editing interfaces are simpler and get the regular job done with a more pleasant blue-and-white interface--Adobe's interface is all dark grey and black and just an ugly interface to put you off. Adobe doesn't let you fix the problem by giving you the use color-freedom settings: Why? Because freedom with assignability, naming, or color selection lets you tailor all the machines in the world for a simple intelligent interface everybody wants! Allowing the use Adobe's software not just for a trivial picture editing tasks, but for how to come up with the perfect photo editing App: did Instagram just make a Billion dollars? So, the one who copyrights what he gets to try from an ideal Adobe program with button assignability, naming, and color selection customers makes Adobe jealous. The simple remedy to all this in 2012 is to just ignore Adobe altogether! Go straight to the web/internet/cloud: just try the more intuitive picture editing programs: try Picnic or Instagram--use your right to buy-and-try--it's cheaper there and relatively risk free: skip off-line picture editing for your laptop: don't waste your money on an off-line program like this Adobe--you're just paying an Adobe programmer all over again to do what a Microsoft programmer was told to do: keep the good features off the less expensive CD-ROM: Adobe and Microsoft still live in the CD-ROM age...offering to pay a programmer at Adobe to do what a programmer at Microsoft was supposed to do--all over again--won't be getting Adobe to be filling in any of the deficits the Microsoft programmer left intentionally at his bosses command...Adobe does just like Microsoft-->it works towards the next sale this way: Adobe uses a harsh and restrictive policy on your freedom to buy-and-try--that customer right that almost every business everywhere respects: because customers help business get rid of competitors this way--Adobe's \\"Buddy, if you try it: you buy it!\\" policy is not the way Adobe should talk to a potential money source...but Adobe's arrogance comes from knowing it has trained and conditioned customers to respect the idea that the customer can't ever open the box: Adobe uses this technicality to bring up another topic: the accusation you copied it!--which Adobe uses as an excuse to keep your money: Quite simply, Adobe should make their software un-copiable, and prosecutible by putting identifying marks in the program to stop anybody from copying it: but the real reason you can't buy-and-try it is: were you to try it, you wouldn't even want a copy of it!--it's junk you'd just want to take it back to get your money back!! This Adobe rip-deal hoping for a dumb package-opening decision is just a check-out counter roach motel: your dollars check in, but they don't check out!--once you take it home and open it, this inferior product is yours: This is sharp-practice software sales, which aims to hard-scam customer money under $100 bucks--Rich companies like Adobe assess fools to be able to take a hit for $100 bucks or less!: figuring fools will be back again to see if giving Adobe 3X the money = Adobe will put only 1/3 the design flaws in this time, again--and proving the gullible customer is now ready to accept a $200+ hit--and still have appetitie for more story of this type, for a return for some more sucker bait: Maybe the $500 program has all the stuff!...don't let them put you on this treadmill of gullibility abuse: Use buy-and-try today on the internet before you buy a CD-ROM: 2012 App programs put these boxed CD-ROM programs to shame--in a 'behind-the-times' category. product_title: Nikon Capture NX 2 Full Version
review_headline: Good, but can be hard to navigate at first, do the 60 day free trial.
review_body: I recently downloaded this as a trial program from Nikon and Adobe lightroom 2. Recently I have been spending more time shooting photos and wanted a program to do adjustments. Photoshop is out of the question for me as a hobbyist, so I looked to these programs based on different magazine, and website recommendations. NX2 is a very solid piece of software, it does what a photographer needs to do, if you are into design than you need Photoshop. I really feel like Nikon designed this for the everyday photographer to the serious hobbyist. The interface is a bit different if you have used other programs in the past, but many of the shortcuts are close to other ones, that it should not take you long to get up and running. In comparing this with Lightroom, both offer very similar features,and it really depends on your flavor. Like other reviewers have stated, you can get a free trial from Nikon for 60 days, so get it and play around with it.

product_title: INDIVIDUAL Home Design Quick & Easy 2.0 (Windows)
review_headline: Easy to use, but not perfect
review_body:
I went ahead and bought this program based on the reviews and its price. I must say that if you have used any other CAD program or the Visio building stencils, this will be an easy program to learn. I opened the my first drawing and started putting together my new house right away.
Creating the rooms were very simple. There were a few times I had to search for an answer (like how to use a jogged wall to create an entry way), but for the most part it was pretty simple.
The main gripe I have with this program is the lack of objects. One area that is totally missing is electrical. You can place where lights belong in the house, but there is no objects for electrical outlets, light switches, phone jacks, or cable/Internet connections. I was surprised because I consider these to be major features.
The other issue I have with the program is that when you print your layout there is alot of whitespace surrounding your drawing. If you try to increase the image size then your drawing gets placed on multiple pages.
Other than these issues I think the program is great. If you are looking for an easy to learn program that will give you the ability to layout your furniture, this program is for you.

I called about this problem, but the fairly knowledgeable help personnel couldn't explain it.

product_title: PDF Converter PRO 7.0 Retail [Old Version]
review_headline: Bait and switch, complete lack of support
review_body:
I bought PDF Pro 6.0 (3 licenses!) a month before they came out with 7.0 and you know what they did? They dropped me like a hot potato. 6.0 was full of bugs that continue to plague me, but Nuance doesn't care. The offered me a VERY EXPENSIVE upgrade path, something like 30% off the retail cost of 7.0, something they offer ALL past customers. Never mind that they just orphaned me and essentially committed fraud by letting me buy three licenses of a piece of crap software that they were about to orphan within a month, without informing me.

Don't buy PDF Creator 7.0. They'll find some way to screw you.

- Their activation system is broken and nags you for activations every few days. This has been going on for years over several versions, and they DON'T CARE.

- Their software is buggy, and they're very slow to fix bugs, and the ones they fix are irrelevant to core functions that are STILL BROKEN.

- If you have any graphics, their software creates PDFs that are 5X larger than Adobe.

- All they do is find new ways of MILKING MONEY OUT OF YOU.

Unfortunately, this is the best PDF software out there, so if you get it, bend over and be prepared to be screwed.

product_title: Microsoft Windows XP Home Edition [Old Version]
review_headline: too much time to train it to what you want
review_body:
I admit it... I was happy with Windows 98 but then someone stole our computer. The replacement came with Windows XP motto \\"we think you want things this way, so don't try to do what you want, we know best\\". If you're a newby you might be happy with this approach, but XP has sucked up hours of time trying to be whipped into line so that it does what I want, in the way that I want it.
For example:
- it's incompatible with ZoneAlarm firewall. Every time Windows updates, Outlook Express permissions on ZoneAlarm have to be reconfigured or you don't get email. 98 didn't have this problem.
- useful programs that I use on my Start Menu disappear if I don't use them. So items used (say) monthly have to be hunted down, requiring more mouse clicks. This is an irritating functionality.
- the Help function is crippled by comparison to 98, unless you are willing to go onto the internet. With phone-line dial-in, this is irritating.
- there is little guidance on setting up Identities for a new user of identities, and some programs will register and operate under some identities but not under others (unless you buy two copies of the program). This means more mouse clicks, or duplicate configuration.
- it assumes you want all of microsoft's products to operate for you. In truth I want Word and Excel to never ever go on the internet, and I never want HTML or Word files to be my basic email mode.
- it assumes that only Windows Media Player is the soundware of choice.
- it takes a long time to close down, to the point where you assume it has failed to shut down. Advice: don't CTRL ALT DEL. Just wait even longer.
Those are the negatives. In sum, XP behaves like a giant bundled amorphous mass, and trying to configure to prevent certain chunks from behaving in an aggressive fashion will take you much time and effort.
However it is relatively stable compared with Windows 98, and most of the configuration can be achieved in time.
On thesegrounds, and given that 98 is no longer supported, it can be recommended.
Martin

product_title: TurboTax Premier Federal & State Returns Plus Federal E-File 2013
review_body: I guess I could wait until I use this specific item before rating which I usually do. In this case I have used Turbo tax for over ten years now and have been greatly satisfied with this product. I remember years and years of filling out paper forms, checking and double checking math and instruction references to assure everything is correct each year with frequent changes to the law. I do taxes for myself and 4 or 5 relatives. The import function of previous years information is effortless which takes the effort of manually tracking and moving data forward. The icing on the cake is 5 free electronic filings available with one purchase. I do not have a formal business, but two of the returns I prepare have multiple rental properties which the premier version handles perfectly.

product_title: TaxCut 2004 Premium [OLD VERSION]
review_headline: Where are the reviews for this year?
review_body:
Look at the reviews and you'll find that those who gave this product a poor rating have never used the most recent addition. I really don't care what someone may think about an old product because it has nothing to do with THIS product. One reviewer ever calls it \\"KTC\\"... sorry but they have not used the name Kiplinger's since the 2000 version.

product_title: Family Tree Maker Platinum [OLD VERSION]
review_headline: Great for those discovering your family history
review_body:
I've used Family Tree Maker for many years now, as well as ancestry.com. If you find that ancestry.com is a bit cumbersome at times, you should give the software a try. Family Tree Maker isn't a fully polished software application, but it does get the job done and when it comes genealogy it's one of the few choices to complete the job. Deciding between the various versions of Family Tree Maker should be fairly simple as there are few noticeable differences. Every year or two I will buy the newest version simply to get the ancestry.com membership that is included with the software.

The Essentials version gives you 1 month of ancestry.com access, the Deluxe gives 3 months and the Platinum 6 months. The platinum also includes some photo software and an additional gift copy, but those are the differences worth noting in my opinion. Using ancestry.com is much more interactive and it has a cleaner interface, but the FTM software provides better importing and exporting features. I tend to find myself working much faster in FTM than I do online.

Is the 2012 version worth an upgrade from previous versions? Like I said, I often upgrade simply for the ancestry.com membership that is included. New to 2012 is the Tree Sync, but it wasn't super impressive. They have also improved some of the guides/tutorials and editing options. Overall, the interface has gotten cleaner, but I still the only true reason for an immediate upgrade is for the membership when you need it.

product_title: Dragon Naturally Speaking 7 Preferred [Old Version]
review_headline: Follow These Simple Tips and It'll Work Great!
review_body:
I just bought Dragon NaturallySpeaking and I've already had a lot of success with it. If you're considering this product, I'd highly recommend it. Initially, I bought it because I'm a lawyer and do a lot of dictating anyway. But I also like to see the words on the screen, which is why I sometimes prefer to type things myself. I figured that Dragon NaturallySpeaking would be the best of both worlds. So far, it's worked pretty well for me. But keep in mind that the software doesn't work perfectly right out of the box. Based on my brief experience with the product, there are several keys to success.
The first is to put in the time doing the voice-recognition training. Unless you teach the software to recognize your voice, it just won't work correctly. There's simply no getting around this. Although it may seem tedious at first, the training will pay off. (Besides, some of the training exercises on the software are very entertaining. For example, you can read President Kennedy's inspiring inaugural address or an excerpt from \\"Dogbert's Top Secret Management Handbook.\\") I spent at least an hour or two training the software when it first arrived and, believe me, it was time well spent. After the initial training period, the more you use it the better it gets because it is constantly \\"learning\\" from its mistakes. As another reviewer has suggested, it probably takes about two months before you'll be really impressed with the product's potential. (But I'm pretty impressed after only a few weeks!)
The second is to buy a decent microphone. A lot of reviewers recommend a USB microphone, but an expensive USB model probably isn't necessary. I have an analog microphone (a Plantronics .Audio 90) and it works just fine. This particular model was far less expensive than most USB microphones that I've seen. The key is to find one that will allow you to position the microphone correctly in relation to your mouth. As the instructions tell you, the positioning of the microphone is essential. Frankly, the one that was included with the software just wasn't up to the task. It always seemed to be too close to my mouth and I was getting very poor results. But as soon as I started using the Plantronics, the accuracy of the software improved dramatically. Trust me, you'll be a a lot happier with the software if you spend a few extra bucks on a good microphone.
Third, although it may seem counterintuitive, you should always speak quickly and naturally when dictating, rather than one word at a time. For some reason, the software is far more accurate when you do. Of course, this is a two-edged sword. If you're really \\"on a roll,\\" and speaking quickly, the software is very accurate. On the other hand, when you just want to insert a word here or there, it really isn't. Consequently, I find that you still have to do some mouse movements when editing your documents. So, although Dragon NaturallySpeaking promises virtually hands-free operation of your computer, don't expect miracles, at least not at first.
Finally, until you really start to master the product, you should probably use the text editor that's included with the software. It's called \\"DragonPad,\\" and I've found that the voice recognition is somewhat more accurate when used with this program than it is with, say, Word or Outlook. Don't ask me why. Besides, it's really not that much of a bother. You can simply cut and paste from DragonPad into whatever application you may be using. When you first start using Dragon NaturallySpeaking, the increased accuracy is worth the extra step. You tend to get less frustrated when it's working the way it's supposed to.
I hope these tips help. Have fun, and remember that practice makes perfect. (Yes, this review was dictated using Dragon NaturallySpeaking.)

product_title: Family Tree Maker 2009 Platinum [OLD VERSION]
review_body: I had no intention of purchasing Family Tree Maker 2009 since I was happy with the FTM 16 version I was using. However, when I became aware that it included a free six-month subscription to Ancestry.com when I was currently paying $29.95 per month for that access, the purchase became a no-brainer. [...]. Wrong! When I called to activate the free subscription, I learned that it is only a free six-month subscription to the US Membership Option. To upgrade that \\"free\\" subscription to the World Edition I need requires me to pay $10 per month for the six-month period. So, I still save $32.21 but nowhere on this site does it say that the free subscription is only to the US option. Nor does it say that on the product box. In fact, the box clearly states that \\"Family Tree Maker Deluxe 2009 comes with six months of free access to Ancestry.com, the world's largest online collection of family history resources\\". I would still recommend the product. I didn't like it at first because it seemed difficult to navigate. But, extensive usage soon let me gain familiarity and the improvements are substantial. It is definitely an industrial-strength genealogy program with features that are quite advanced when compared to the FTM 16 version I was using. The only area in which I would downgrade it is that report generation is too slow and takes far longer when compared to generating reports with my prior version. I've also noticed some character conversion problems that I'm assuming will be fixed with a version update. My main point, though, is that potential purchasers should be aware that the free six-months of free access is to US records only. World access will require you to pay $10 per month during that six-month period. It should not be that complicated to make that point clear in marketing materials.

product_title: Microsoft Windows Home Premium 7 English ROW DVD
review_body: When I loaded my brand new full version of Windows 7 Home Premium on my brand new Apple iMac (using Boot Camp to partition the drive), the product code did not work. I went on line and found that a lot of other people are having the same problem, but I could not find a solution. Microsoft's help site offered the following explanation for my problem: (1) I didn't enter the code correctly, (2) I was using counterfeit software; or (3) I was trying to use the same software on two different PCs and should buy a new license. IOW, I am either a moron or a thief. So with heavy heart, I sought help from Microsoft by telephone. After spending two days in Microsoft hell talking to reps around the world, I learned that, although the disc and box it came in were labeled \\"Home Premium,\\" the disc contained Home Basic. Microsoft's proposed solution was to give me a Windows 7 Home Basic product code for me to load Home Basic on my PC and then I could BUY an update to Home Premium. Not a very good solution for a problem that was entirely Microsoft's fault, but I was unwilling to invest any more time or frustration dealing with Microsoft customer service. At one point, a rep had the nerve to tell me that I should not have bought the product from Amazon because it deals in counterfeit goods. Luckily, Amazon actually has a functioning customer service system, and I was able to exchange the defective disk for a new one within minutes and with Amazon paying for shipping coming and going. Thank you Amazon. [[ASIN:B002DHGMK0 Microsoft Windows 7 Home Premium]]

product_title: PowerDirector 9 Ultra - 64
review_headline: Trial version works, with a few wrinkles
review_body: I looked at PowerDirector because I'd been using Adobe Premiere Elements (APE), versions 7 and 8, and have too many crashes and other issues; despite even buying and using a highly spec'd new machine. I used APE since 2009, mostly on AVCHD source. The machine I'm using is a Sony VAIO VPCF1, Intel i7, with Windows 7, 8G RAM, 500G 7200RPM hard drive, external Western Digital eSata drive. I purchased this machine in November 2010, with APE version 8 preloaded. I loaded previous projects created on APE 7, but couldn't get past a fatal crash that would occur outputting to .m2ts. I downloaded the PowerDirector version 9 trial version, keeping in mind the controversial reviews I've read here. Actually, I didn't search for PowerDirector based on Amazon reviews, but on other forum comments around the net recommending this software. On to the details of my PowerDirector experience: Pros: It loads quickly, ready for editing within less than 15 seconds. There are several preview resolutions available, so I could choose a level that works almost seamlessly in real time as I move back and forth along the timeline. Outputting AVCHD output (\\"Production\\") of my 6 minute video took about 15 minutes. No crashes or hangs whatsoever. Applying video \\"fix\\" effects can be done over all clips quickly; not available with APE. With PowerDirector, a title can be editted several times after being created. With APE, it's turned into an uneditable video clip after creation. Cons: I had to fiddle a bit to get used to splitting and trimming clips, but in all fairness that's a learning curve problem; not the software's fault. Here APE is a bit more intuitive. Fades out or in took a bit of time to learn how to apply (APE has menu pulldowns). Some transition effects didn't work immediately. Closing the program and re-opening solved the transition issue. (Since PowerDirector loads fast, this workaround to the transitions flakeyness cost less than a minute each of 3-4 times I didit. In the future, I might just tolerate it and maybe reload once after finishing other work.) I found a bug: I had two title effects, at the beginning and the end of my video. Though the title effects look fine while editting, the first title would be missing on the output video file. Workaround: I found on the Cyberlink PowerDirector forum that others fixed this little problem by simply moving the title to another video track. That worked for me. So I was able to create my video with all my titles intact, no crashes. Though there are issues, I was able to overcome all and get my video created. Yesterday I created 30 minute AVCHD video without any problems. So based on this experience, and not trusting APE anymore, I'll go ahead and buy the PowerDirector 9 Ultra64 version. My latest video on YouTube: [...]

product_title: AutoCAD LT 2002
review_body:
I divide land, design and build tracts, and used AutoCAD LT as the [less costly] industry standard for computer drafting inputs to engineers, architects and surveyors. And while LT 2002 does include a few of the important innovations of AutoCAD 2002, its capabilities are still strictly limited to 2-D drawing. Definition used below time in/out, 1 in to 4 saved = 1/4.
True to form and the army of programmers, support staff and professionals, compatibility is one of the key advantages of LT 2002. It is 100 percent DWG-compatible with AutoCAD 2000-, 2000i-, and 2002-based products, allowing me to open, edit, and exchange drawing files with my engineers, surveyors, blueprint shop and partner in Hawaii.
I used successfully the Web publishing tools included, worked, however a bit laborious, time in vs. time saved 1/2. eTransmit, for example, puts drawings you currently have open--with all associated files and x-refs--into a single set so that I could edit the file on another machine. Necessary component of a file is present without the user having to individually select all related files. Users can then post the transmitted set on the Internet and send it as an attachment via e-mail, even while changing ISPs a couple of times. Additional Web publishing enhancements, such as templates and themes, have been improved dramatically and all worked.
Associative dimensioning works and time in/out 1/4. If you modify a geometric object in a drawing, associative dimensioning automatically adjusts all dimensions associated with that object. Got rid of the need to manually update or re-create dimensions for changes in geometry. All in all, this is a very useful feature. However, it does make it more difficult for users who have grown accustomed to manually forcing dimensions of objects in their drawings. Saved tons of time on text, the dimensions immediately change. New layer, text, and attribute tools, such as text scaling, the enhanced attribute editor, block attributemanager, layer translator, all work.
Tutorials and product support will speed up the two days of required start up traing, very easy to learn, but time intensive in the box) provides step-by-step instructions on all of AutoCAD LT 2002's features using interesting and real-life sample files.
